commit_message:
Backlog spec describing Nova's quota needs

This is to aid cross project discussion on quotas, we can discuss what
Nova sees as its current quota needs.

This starts to hint at the relationship between the Placement API
definition of Resource Classes and the management of quotas.
It also adopts the concept of limits being stored in Keystone.

Change-Id: I4e757f7e67b304ee05536137f4862e242684de55
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/78/429678/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============ Quota Reboot ============ The quota system is no longer meeting all our users needs. On top of that the current implementation has proven to be unreliable due to races. This proposes what is needed from a new quota system for Nova's users. Problem description =================== The current quota system is known to be "leak" quota over time, particularly when a particular project performs lots of builds and deletes. It has proved hard to reproduce or pin down the exact cause of these issues. Some functional tests to stress quotas is a must. Cells v2 work has forced a rethink to the quotas, and we are now looking at just counting resources and checking limits in the API, rather than attempting to manage reservations spanning multiple cells: http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/ocata/approved/cells-count-resources-to-check-quota-in-api.html There are plans to move towards using placement to better model and query the current resource usage. Cinder has introduced a system that works with hierarchical project supported that has been added into keystone: https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/kilo/approved/nested-quota-driver-api.html However, the above model only allows a parent project to delegate a fixed portion of the quota to a child project. It doesn't allow the over allocation of quota between sub projects. Overall, we need a unified approach to quotas that can be applied across all relevant OpenStack projects, as required. That is not to be confused with wanting a unified system, more a unified pattern like we have for policy and configuration. Use Cases ---------- TODO... it feels like we are missing use cases here Quotas are the tool to ensure people use their fair share of resources within the cloud. Lets look at two ends of the spectrum. Maximise utilization -------------------- Many private clouds are built to help get better utilization of a companies investments in IT infrastructure. Before the availability of multi-tenant solutions for sharing IT resources, infrastructure would be purchased more on a per project and per department basis, leading to lots of different hardware that all tends to have quite low levels of utilization. Private clouds help organizations pool resources, ensure that overall less infrastructure needs to be run, and being centralised and standardised it can be run more efficiently. In these clouds, you want to maximise the utilization of your investment. This usually means you will give departments more quota than the current capacity of your cloud, knowing that not all departments will use 100% of their quota. The billing / chargeback system usually helps ensure people only consume what they need. When usage gets close to capacity, you can adjust as required either the quota or the capacity of the system. In some cases departments may ask for the quota to be decreased to help them manage their expenses. Public clouds are often a similar strategy. Capacity is generally added all the time to meet the expected level of demand growth. Quota can be many 1000s of times greater than the actually capacity of the cloud. Billing is the main limit that stops people consuming all of their quota. The quota is really just a tool to manage the risk of a user that is unable to pay their usage bill at the end of the month. For example, you could offer prepayment of resources to allow for an increase in quota. Divide capacity between departments ----------------------------------- Some clouds have users with many times the amount of work than the capacity of the cloud, such as in scientific research clouds. It is common for the cloud to be divided up based on things like the contribution each department made to the cost of the cloud. Where it is common for users to be consuming most, if not all, of their quota, the operator wants to ensure they hand out no more quota than the total capacity of the cloud. Hierarchy and Quota ------------------- It is common for a department to be paying the bill for cloud resources, but it wants to divide up the allowance it gets between various groups or projects that the department wants to fund. For example, you might have a "production" group that has you want to have access to all of your floating IPs. As above, its possible the department would like to divide quota up evenly between each of its projects, or just apply some loose limits so no project takes up half of the total capacity. Domains ------- All of this is talking about projects and nested projects. Domains have not really come into this discussion. If we consider a Domain as the ultimate parent of any chain of nested projects, we are probably OK in terms of use cases. This assumes the system knows that you may have the same project in two different domains. Resource Specific Quota ----------------------- Consider offering both ironic resources and virtual resources in the same cloud. Really you want different pools of quota for each type of resource. If you limit purely on vCPUs, having enough quota for a single ironic instance may give you quota to build an incredibly large number of virtual machines. This was originally discussed in flavor classes: https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/backlog/approved/flavor-class.html With the new ironic custom resource classes in the Placement API, we are better served by looking at moving to restricting Quota templates --------------- When setting a quota limit, currently you have to manually set every rule that you want to be different from the default project quota in the configuration. It would be easier if you could instead define a set of quota classes, and apply the appropriate class to each scope. If you update one of the quota classes, there is no longer a need to update every single scope. For example, if you want to have a separate quota for ironic resources, you may want to give a certain class of user twice as much quota. Currently that would involve updating every relevant scope to add the additional quota. Checking Quota -------------- Currently, you have to force a quota if you apply a quota that is smaller than the existing scope's resource usage. While this is a useful check, there are other sanity check that could be useful. It would be good to be able to compare the current capacity of the whole system with the amount of quota handed out. In a similar way, when doing hierarchical quotas, you want to see what the level of over-commit in quota is between all the sub scopes of a given parent scope. Ideally it would be easy to query what users are current close, at, or other their quota limits. You can contact the affected people and discuss how to increase their quota. Proposed change =============== Move to checking limits ----------------------- Here are the steps for checking quota for a given request: * define what resources are required for the request * look up what limits apply for those resources and then given token * find the existing usage for each scoped resource limit * fail request if limits will be exceeded TODO... If we take the count resources approach, what we need to do is work out what resources limits apply for the given user. We can then work out what the current resource usage is in the system, then add the increase in resources being requested, then compare that to the stored limits. As placement allows us to make an atomic claim of the resources, we can double check for any quota violations after making the atomic claim for the additional resources, or ideally part of the claim process. Scope ----- A given user token defines the scope of the resource limit. Lets consider the content of the token, and the possible scopes: * user_id (u1) * project_id (p1) * associated project hierarchy (d1 -> p2 -> p1 (-> p0)) * default project limit, if no specific limit found * domain_id (d1) It should be possible to attach a limit to any of these scopes: u1, p1, p2 (i.e the parent of project p1), d1 Note, should there be no limits discovered, we fall back to the default policy as defined in the that by default, project limits come from the conf file. Lets consider the quota checking process defined about. The scope is relevant for these steps: * look up what limits apply for those resources and then given token * find the existing usage for each scoped resource limit When looking up either the limit or the existing usage count, it is easier for the user_id, project_id (and domain_id once supported), as they are generally attributes of the associated object we are looking up. What is hard to lookup efficiently is the nested project. Lets consider the look ups associated with p2. Firstly we need to look up the the fact p2 is the parent of p1, this is not currently in the token (TODO?). Looking up the limits of p2 is straight forward, but now consider the resource count for that limit. We need to look up all the children tenants of p2 and then get the full list of active instances for all of those tenants. TODO - consider supporting domain_id, and quotas scope to domain_id so its more efficient than looking at nested projects. Good enough for 80%? TODO - discuss default quota limits, such as project limits in conf, and user and domain defaulting to unlimited. So for a given request, we get the following scope: * domain_id (e.g. d1) * list of parent project_id ([] is allowed) (e.g. [p2]) * project_id (e.g. p1) * user_id (e.g. u1) We can set resource limits that define the following: * domain_id (required) * project_id or <any> * user_id or <any> * Note: either project_id or user_id should be set To look up what limits apply, we are looking for something that matches: * domain_id == d1 * project_id == <any> or p1 or p2 * user_id == <any> or u1 Scopes to check (do the cheapest count first, for efficiency): * If there are any limits with user_id == u1, we check the user limits, otherwise default to unlimited use of project quota * If there are any limits with project_id == p1, that scope is checked, otherwise do a check of the default project quota in the conf * If there are any limits with project_id == p2, that scope is checked Note this means: * by default, each user has unlimited usage of their per project quota * if any parent project has a quota, this check is in additional to the check of quota for the project_id (either the conf default project quota or any project specific override). * Note: Cinder has gone for defaulting to zero quota, if a parent has quota set, and the child project has no specific quota. This is because there is no overcommit in child quotas, which allows for efficient checking of the quota, as only the child project scope needs to be considered. Resource Specific Quota ----------------------- Now the placement API has given us a way to describe a resource request for each build request. We should move the Quota to apply to the same set of resources. In the simplest sense, we get a Disk, VCPU and RAM amount for virtual resources, and soon ironic resources will instead request a particular custom resource class. It might be we want to allow limits on the number of each custom resource class, and separately consider disk vcpu and RAM. To achieve this, lets consider the concept of a Resource Class Limit. It is the maximum quantity allowed for the given scope. TODO - what about qualitative things, should we limit the counts? Quota Class ----------- When setting quota, in many scenarios you really want to set one of a predefined set of limits, rather than having to hand craft the set of quotas each time, or copy them from some post-it note. To make this possible we can allow a user to define a Quota class. This is a set of overides Project hierarchy ----------------- For a particular token, we know what domain and what project the token relates to. We can also find out what projects are related to that given project. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- TODO REST API impact --------------- TODO Security impact --------------- TODO Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- TODO - CLI Performance Impact ------------------ TODO - extra resource usage checks expensive Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: None Other contributors: John Garbutt (johnthetubaguy) Work Items ---------- TODO Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= None Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== None History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Pike - Introduced

added_lines: # # Class to load default Glance metadata definitions # # == Parameters # # [*extra_params*] # (optional) String of extra command line parameters to append to the # glance-manage db_load_metadefs command. These will be inserted in the # command line between 'glance-manage' and 'db_load_metadefs'. # Defaults to '' # class glance::db::metadefs( $extra_params = '', ) { include ::glance::deps include ::glance::params exec { 'glance-manage db_load_metadefs': command => "glance-manage ${extra_params} db_load_metadefs", path => '/usr/bin', user => 'glance', refreshonly => true, try_sleep => 5, tries => 10, logoutput => on_failure, subscribe => [ Anchor['glance::install::end'], Anchor['glance::config::end'], Anchor['glance::dbsync::end'] ], } }

commit_message:
Add better support for multi-OS deployments

This change adds a few variables which allow it to consume a repo-server
setup which has releases based on OS and ARCH. The changes require a
deployer to have at least one repo-server per-OS type being deployed.
This means that if a deployer wanted to do a mixed CentOS 7 and Ubuntu
16.04 deployment they'd need at least one repo server in each of OS type
which facilitates the building of wheels for each OS.

Change-Id: Ifd5ff22ae47bc9a2a88c1bbb2632ce48ba5accbf
Closes-Bug: 1641131
Depends-On: I3f36afa307e02a38d73b860fc23ed94a09882c34
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
(cherry picked from commit cacf41028b1fe398175d34cc298ce39042edf09e)

commit_message:
Check if changes have made before attempting a rebalance

Utilize the "ringbuilder.devs_changed" option to ensure that the ring
needs a rebalance. This will prevent unnecessary rebalances that cause
failures due to "min_part_hours" not being passed even though no changes
were required.

Additionally, we can now return a correct Ansible repsonse when the ring
has changed/rebalanced - and return "OK" when it hasn't returned at all.

Change-Id: I1fb4b3544a50ab5f566b3846d616107a84ff29c9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_swift refs/changes/47/447447/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Clean up injected role vars

Injected role vars, in cases where the vars were not generated
within the playbook run, are not ideal. In the case of our venv vars,
it removes the ability for a deploy to manipulate the venv download
tag or path using group vars.

This cleanup standardizes the venv tag and download url vars using
group vars.
I also removed several unnecessary definitions of
pip_lock_to_internal_repo in the playbooks since it is already
defined in the group_vars/all.yml.

commit_message:
Fail deployment if non-existent block devices are passed for OSDs

If a user passes a block device, e.g. /dev/sdx, that doesn't actually
exist, then the user made a mistake and the deployment should fail.
Without this change if /dev/sdx doesn't exist, then a directory is
created called /dev/sdx and set up as a directory-backed OSD. This
patch adds a check to fail the deployment if the requested OSD is
a directory with a name starting with /dev.

Change-Id: I5f03fc332b8df3914dc8609a203eb38693cb87a7
Closes-Bug: 1665697

commit_message:
remove hacking rule that enforces log translation

Log translation is no longer being done [1] [2] so there
is no point in enforcing it going forwards.

Remove the hacking enforcement so that new commits need
not include this unused feature and so that we can remove
this unused il8n markup in existing code.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-March/thread.html#113365
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/446762/

Change-Id: I31f35b0597e161a1654467f5a0a2348789292d83
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/89/446789/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: log_translation = re.compile( r"(.)*LOG\.(audit|error|info|critical|exception)\(\s*('|\")") log_translation_LC = re.compile( r"(.)*LOG\.(critical)\(\s*(_\(|'|\")") log_translation_LE = re.compile( r"(.)*LOG\.(error|exception)\(\s*(_\(|'|\")") log_translation_LI = re.compile( r"(.)*LOG\.(info)\(\s*(_\(|'|\")") log_translation_LW = re.compile( r"(.)*LOG\.(warning|warn)\(\s*(_\(|'|\")")def validate_log_translations(logical_line, physical_line, filename): # Translations are not required in the test and tempest # directories. if ("manila/tests" in filename or "manila_tempest_tests" in filename or "contrib/tempest" in filename): return if pep8.noqa(physical_line): return msg = "M327: LOG.critical messages require translations `_LC()`!" if log_translation_LC.match(logical_line): yield (0, msg) msg = ("M328: LOG.error and LOG.exception messages require translations " "`_LE()`!") if log_translation_LE.match(logical_line): yield (0, msg) msg = "M329: LOG.info messages require translations `_LI()`!" if log_translation_LI.match(logical_line): yield (0, msg) msg = "M330: LOG.warning messages require translations `_LW()`!" if log_translation_LW.match(logical_line): yield (0, msg) msg = "M331: Log messages require translations!" if log_translation.match(logical_line): yield (0, msg) register(validate_log_translations)

commit_message:
Don't try to run os-net-config from yum_update.sh

The UpdateDeployment already depends on NetworkDeployment.
We should not run os-net-config unconditionally before update.

Closes-Bug: #1666227

Change-Id: I48cbf5de00d47c6fdad71ff24c00e9db05cec5d5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/06/444906/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # Writes any changes caused by alterations to os-net-config and bounces the # interfaces *before* restarting the cluster. os-net-config -c /etc/os-net-config/config.json -v --detailed-exit-codes RETVAL=$? if [[ $RETVAL == 2 ]]; then echo "os-net-config: interface configuration files updated successfully" elif [[ $RETVAL != 0 ]]; then echo "ERROR: os-net-config configuration failed" exit $RETVAL fi

commit_message:
Bind redis-sentinel to its network

We currently do not bind redis-sentinel to any IP:
redis      21144  0.0  0.0 142908  5908 ?        Ssl  07:43   0:11 /usr/bin/redis-sentinel *:26379 [sentinel]

Let's bind it to the same network as redis.

Change-Id: I8a782ae1db84eb614aa3995a1638a2f370e70d06
Partial-Bug: #1673715
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/56/446956/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
raise the version of appdirs to match what virtualenv uses

We're trying to install incompatible versions of appdirs, and in the
process breaking when we try to toggle back and forth [1]. Raise the
version of appdirs used to match what virtualenv brings with it to start
so that we avoid the toggle.

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/86/445186/3/check/gate-tempest-dsvm-neutron-src-cliff-ubuntu-xenial/2f8c8c0/logs/devstacklog.txt.gz#_2017-03-16_17_55_48_873

Change-Id: Ia95bbb7e4dd3503bf87559a118c0b197151fde16
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Update deprecated allocation ratios

The nova allocation ratio settings have been moved from the scheduler to
the main nova class. They are being removed from the scheduler class and
need to be passed to nova differently.

Change-Id: I753c795ef62a505b7b2499b3805acb43d1f79b4d
Closes-Bug: #1673893

commit_message:
Drop MANIFEST.in

Pbr generates a sensible manifest from git files and some standard files.
So MANIFEST.in is not needed by pbr.

Change-Id: If79b808f94ecf35a2cf70a6a119e70cd4a07edc6

commit_message:
Fixes router external_fixed_ip tests sometimes failing with Conflict.

Currently, a Conflict is thrown for tests like
test_create_router_external_fixed_ips because an IP address will
already be in use, due to improper clean up in other tests,
causing this test to throw a Conflict exception.

Change-Id: Iec090d4740c2fd7e230086e3e35e25ef8812ba71
Closes-Bug: #1673290
Partial-Bug: #1670553

commit_message:
Adding Openstack support for Xenial

Openstack dropped support for Ubuntu-trusty,
changed to xenial to avoid conflicts with devstack

Change-Id: I9e192b47d7f30cb412a4177947225c39db749073
Closes-bug: #1673704

subject: Include 'deprecation' as a flag
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-02-14 14:24:37.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-doc-tools/commit/bc60adf19aecfc4e2e871b8be8ff4cd72cb018e8', 'message': "Include 'deprecation' as a flag

There is support for displaying deprecation information in a somewhat
structured manner (proper lists, emphasis on titles, etc.). However, the
deprecation information is still included in the help text rather than
in this flags section. This makes things more difficult than they need
to be.

Resolve this by instead including any deprecation information in the
flags section. This will transform output from something like this:

  (String) DEPRECATED: Host to locate redis. Replaced by
  [DEFAULT]/transport_url

to this:

  (String) Host to locate redis.

  Deprecated
    Replaced by [DEFAULT]/transport_url

Which should be a little more obvious.

Change-Id: Ifaee90a814fa3efee8b41eb0411535cff70e7309

"}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2017-02-21 19:14:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-doc-tools/commit/86eb71ef325caa80f24ced207b4bd3d1a95d8ad6', 'message': "Include 'deprecation' as a flag

There is support for displaying deprecation information in a somewhat
structured manner (proper lists, emphasis on titles, etc.). However, the
deprecation information is still included in the help text rather than
in this flags section. This makes things more difficult than they need
to be.

Resolve this by instead including any deprecation information in the
flags section. This will transform output from something like this:

  (String) DEPRECATED: Host to locate redis. Replaced by
  [DEFAULT]/transport_url

to this:

  (String) Host to locate redis.

    Replaced by [DEFAULT]/transport_url

Which should be a little more obvious.

commit_message:
Include 'deprecation' as a flag

There is support for displaying deprecation information in a somewhat
structured manner (proper lists, emphasis on titles, etc.). However, the
deprecation information is still included in the help text rather than
in this flags section. This makes things more difficult than they need
to be.

Resolve this by instead including any deprecation information in the
flags section. This will transform output from something like this:

  (String) DEPRECATED: Host to locate redis. Replaced by
  [DEFAULT]/transport_url

to this:

  (String) Host to locate redis.

  Deprecated
    Replaced by [DEFAULT]/transport_url

Which should be a little more obvious.

It's necessary to fix the template, which added the flags at the same
level as the title and description, resulting in varying numbers of
bullet points for the list.

Change-Id: Ifaee90a814fa3efee8b41eb0411535cff70e7309

deleted_lines: if option.deprecated_for_removal: if not option.help.strip().startswith('DEPRECATED'): helptext = 'DEPRECATED: ' + helptext if getattr(option, 'deprecated_reason', None): helptext += ' ' helptext += option.deprecated_reason.lstrip().rstrip()

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary parameter

With the removal of docbook support, we now support a single type of
output. As such, the aforementioned option is surplus to requirements
and can be removed. Do just this.

Change-Id: Ib9d49fd465ecceb92075495de966b2189a371103

commit_message:
Avoid setuptools 34.0.0-34.3.0

Recent bugs in setuptools 34.0.0-34.3.0 caused race condition replacing
a setuptools dependency "IOError METADATA no such file", we will install
the latest version of setuptools which is 34.3.0, by specifying version
in requirements.txt, we can avoid the bug. This can be reverted once
the bug is fixed in newer setuptools version.

Change-Id: If1768a3c7c1e361f55f7349b2e960361285c1b47
Link: https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/issues/951
Related-Bug: #1667545

commit_message:
coordination: remove started check

It'd be a programming error to join any group before the coordination is
started, and that's not done anywhere.

anyway.

commit_message:
coordination: stop checking for _coordinator to be None

There's no code that should call the coordinator after is has been stop, so
there should not be any need to check for that anyway. Or the program would
have to be fixed!

Change-Id: I3ed1838828b5ad9817678d4c094afbb9115eaf78

commit_message:
coordination: create coordinator at init time

This also switches the coordination to zake:// in test so the code actually
works like it would with a production-ready coordinator.

Change-Id: I38f6a3389f70bed6b45fa7526a13d0484bfc9c3f

commit_message:
Correctly detect IPv6 addresses

Use the is_ip function from charmhelpers to correctly
detect and return IPv4 and IPv6 addresses.

Support DNS querying for IPv6 addresses using ipv6
argument (defaults to false).

Resync tox.ini from release tools to resolve libcharmstore
compatibility issues for 1.25.x testing.

Change-Id: I719ac7db350b2b257ae057acc4299a8e97501a7b
Partial-Bug: 1622780
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-percona-cluster refs/changes/73/443073/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: is_ip, if is_ip(hostname): else: answers = None try: # Attempt IPv6 first answers = dns.resolver.query(hostname, 'AAAA') except dns.resolver.NXDOMAIN: # Fallback to IPv4 # This may throw an NXDOMAIN exception; in which case # things are badly broken so just let it kill the hook answers = dns.resolver.query(hostname, 'A')
deleted_lines: try: # Test to see if already an IPv4 address socket.inet_aton(hostname) except socket.error: # This may throw an NXDOMAIN exception; in which case # things are badly broken so just let it kill the hook answers = dns.resolver.query(hostname, 'A')

commit_message:
Turn on SSH for Keystone for all distros.

With the previous patch that was done to enable SSH access, it was
mistakingly done to be handled only in the Ubuntu case.  It should
always be done as SSH is always needed.

This is only a problem for the backport, the change introduced in
master and stable/ocata relies on the new configure_user macro
which runs regardless.

Change-Id: Ibef580748cc139f0ebf207609f934f1469222624
Closes-Bug: #1635795
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/26/447226/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: && chmod 0755 /var/run/sshdRUN chsh -s /bin/bash keystone \ && chmod 755 /usr/local/bin/kolla_extend_start

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-09 22:49:43.000000000', 'files': ['brick_cinderclient_ext/client.py', 'brick_cinderclient_ext/tests/unit/test_brick_client.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-brick-cinderclient-ext/commit/abe1520bc2f5c7dc7abc2df8e6f5f7416961b07f', 'message': 'Retrieve storage_protocol from storage backend capabilities

Currently, local_attach() verifies storage_protocol from

We can check storage_protocol from storage backend

commit_message:
Retrieve storage_protocol from storage backend capabilities

Currently, local_attach() verifies storage_protocol from
connection_info using initialize_connection(), but this
operation is high cost because this operates storage backend
directly.

We can check storage_protocol from storage backend
capabilities using capabilities.get(host), therefore
we should change the way to retrieve storage_protocol.

Change-Id: I5aed2ba7ee086260de9a11b01116a330e239174c
Closes-Bug: #1648900

commit_message:
Remove bandit.yaml in favor of default config

Latest g-r version of bandit does not require a bandit.yaml. This
removes the bandit.yaml and skips the same tests that were not
run as defined by the profile before. This patch also puts running
of bandit within the pep8 testenv, consistent with other projects.

Change-Id: I7db8bc460e2051c635dc7b3fd4b152ece80c7a0c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/38/444538/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # The following bandit tests are being skipped: # B101: Test for use of assert # B104: Test for binding to all interfaces # B107: Test for use of hard-coded password argument defaults # B110: Try, Except, Pass detected. # B112: Test for a continue in the except block # B310: Audit url open for permitted schemes # B311: Standard pseudo-random generators are not suitable for security/cryptographic purposes # B404: Import of subprocess module # B410: Import of lxml module # B504: Test for SSL use with no version specified # B506: Test for use of yaml load # B603: Test for use of subprocess with shell equals true # B607: Test for starting a process with a partial path bandit -r heat -x tests --skip B101,B104,B107,B110,B112,B310,B311,B404,B410,B504,B506,B603,B607# The following bandit tests are being skipped: # B101: Test for use of assert # B104: Test for binding to all interfaces # B107: Test for use of hard-coded password argument defaults # B110: Try, Except, Pass detected. # B112: Test for a continue in the except block # B310: Audit url open for permitted schemes # B311: Standard pseudo-random generators are not suitable for security/cryptographic purposes # B404: Import of subprocess module # B410: Import of lxml module # B504: Test for SSL use with no version specified # B506: Test for use of yaml load # B603: Test for use of subprocess with shell equals true # B607: Test for starting a process with a partial path commands = bandit -r heat -x tests --skip B101,B104,B107,B110,B112,B310,B311,B404,B410,B504,B506,B603,B607

subject: Live Migration of Rescued Instances
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-26 07:28:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs/commit/c43f047e85cb6cfe9aadc3af8f73667ead341366', 'message': "Live Migration of Rescued Instances

When an instance is rescued the libvirt driver creates a file in the
instance directory that contains the original instance xml. This file
is used when unrescuing the instance to revert to the original disk
configuration. However, this file is not necessary to restore the
instance's original configuration. Furthermore the reliance on this
file means we currently cannot live migrate a rescued instance. Thus
it is proposed that we do not create this file during the rescue
operation and rebuild the instance's original xml file from the
database when we unrescue it.

APIImpact

commit_message:
Live Migration of Rescued Instances

Add support to live migrate rescued instances. Currently instances
in rescued state cannot be live migrated. This might be an issue
during upgrades as all the active instances in the host needs
to be migrated using live-migrate.

The spec proposes a way to add support for live-migrating
rescued instances for libvirt driver.

NOTE: This spec is based on originally approved spec
http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/
newton/approved/live-migrate-rescued-instances.html

APIImpact

blueprint live-migrate-rescued-instances

Change-Id: Ib0b35b9a99a689b27ce1a87a8bec4d0186fc4543
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/61/347161/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================================ ============================================================ Blueprint:https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/live-migrate-rescued-instances When an instance is rescued the libvirt driver creates a file in the instance directory that contains the original instance xml. This file is used when unrescuing the instance to revert to the original disk configuration. However, this file is not necessary to restore the instance's original configuration. Furthermore the reliance on this file means we currently cannot live migrate a rescued instance. Thus it is proposed that we do not create this file during the rescue operation and rebuild the instance's original xml file from the database when we unrescue it. Problem description =================== At present operators cannot live migrate rescued instances. Use Cases ---------- As an operator of an OpenStack cloud, I like to live migrate all active instances on a node in order to perform maintenance. Proposed change =============== The Live migration method in the compute manager will be amended to permit migration of instances in a rescued state. The implementation of rescue and live migration operations are different for each driver. Hyper-V Have recently added support for rescue and live migration of rescued instances is supported. VMware Does not currently support live migration of instances across compute nodes but proposed patch https://review.openstack.org/#/c/270116/ will address this. When this is implemented live migration of rescued instances will be supported. XenAPI and Libvirt Do not currently support the live migration of rescued instances due to information stored locally on the compute node when an instance is rescued. Live migration does not copy this information to the target compute node so a subsequent unrescue operation would fail. The proposal is to amend how rescue and unrescue are implemented in the XenAPI and Libvirt drivers. In the libvirt driver rescue method saves the current domain xml in a local file and the unrescue method uses this to revert the instance to its previous setup, i.e. booting from instance primary disk again rather than rescueimage. However saving the previous state in the domain xml file is unnecessary since during unrescue the domain is destroyed and restarted. This is effectively a hard reboot so I just call hard reboot during the unrescue operation. Hard reboot rebuilds the domain xml from the nova database so the domain xml file is not needed. A similar approach is proposed for XenAPI. in order to support drivers that do not support live migration of instances in a rescued state a new driver capabilities flag will be added called code:`supports_live_migrate_rescued`. This will be set to False for drivers that do not support the migration of rescued instances. If the driver supports live migration of instances in a rescued state the os-migrateLive action API call will return a response code of 202 instead of 409 when an attempt is made to perform a live migration of an instance in a rescued state so a new API microversion will be introduced. If the driver does not support live migration of instances in a rescued state then a 400 response will be returned with a message indicating that the driver does not support live migration of instances in a rescued state. The response message will identify the compute node that does not support live migration of rescued instances, i.e. source or destination and compute node name. This is useful during upgrade when some compute nodes may not yet have been upgraded to the version that supports the migration of rescued instances. Live migration already preserves the current instance status whether the migration successful or rolled back. Alternatives ------------ One alternative is not doing this, leaving it up to operators to ask the user to unrescue their instance so it can be migrated. Another option is to write the original instance state to the database during the rescue operation so that it can be retrieved by the target compute node during unrescue. However this is unnecessary and would require a database schema change to add a table to store this information. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- To be added in a new microversion. This is required because a live migration operation on an instance in a rescued state will return 202 instead of the current 409 response. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- User attemting to unrescue an instance whilst a migration was in progress would be prevented from doing so until the migration was complete. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- During upgrade live migrations of rescued instances may fail with a 400 response due to one of the source or destination nodes not yet being upgraded. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Paul Carlton (irc: paul-carlton2) Other assignees: None Work Items ---------- * Change compute API live migration methods to allow migration of rescued instances. * Bump python-novaclient API version. * Change libvirt driver rescue and unrescue functions. * Change compute manager unrescue to pass context object to virt/driver unrescue method and change implementations of virt/driver unrescue to accept context parameter (This is required by libvirt driver unrescue in order to utilize the driver's hard_reboot method) * Change XenAPI driver rescue and unrescue methods to remove the use of information held locally on the compute node. * Implement a driver capability check to if the driver supports live migration of rescued instances. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit tests will be added as required. Also tempest tests to verify the use of live migration of an instance in a rescued state and subsequent unrescuing of the instance. Documentation Impact ==================== New API needs to be documented: * Compute API extensions documentation http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-compute-v2.1.html * nova.compute.api documentation http://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/api/nova.compute.api.html References ========== https://review.openstack.org/#/c/308198 History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Newton - Introduced

commit_message:
conf: fix default values reporting infra worker

Default values set for console_host and
xenserver.console_public_hostname are reporting the details of the
infra worker or some python code,, thus making it unclear what the
real default value should be.

Change-Id: Iba7bf16ba30958d9c4008cc2fbf77cd9f64cf5a3
Closes-Bug: 1669847
Implements: blueprint centralize-config-options-pike

add release notes for 0.9.0

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/28/446628/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ============ Rally v0.9.9 ============ Overview -------- +------------------+-----------------------+ | Release date | **3/16/2017** | +------------------+-----------------------+ Details ------- TBD Plugins ~~~~~~~ **All** Fix a bunch of JSON schemas which are used for validation of all plugins. **Deployment Engines**: *Updated* Extend `DevstackEngine <http://rally.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/plugin_reference.html#devstackengine-engine>`_ with ``enable_plugin`` option. **Validators**: *Updated* Extend ``required_contexts`` validator to support ``at least one of the`` logic. **Scenarios**: * *NEW!!* - `CinderVolumeTypes.create_and_set_volume_type_keys <http://rally.readthedocs.io/en/0.9.0/plugins/plugin_reference.html#cindervolumetypes-create-and-set-volume-type-keys-scenario>`_ - `KeystoneBasic.create_and_list_roles <http://rally.readthedocs.io/en/0.9.0/plugins/plugin_reference.html#keystonebasic-create-and-list-roles-scenario>`_ - `KeystoneBasic.create_and_update_user <http://rally.readthedocs.io/en/0.9.0/plugins/plugin_reference.html#keystonebasic-create-and-update-user-scenario>`_ - `NovaServers.resize_shutoff_server <http://rally.readthedocs.io/en/0.9.0/plugins/plugin_reference.html#novaservers-resize-shutoff-server-scenario>`_ Fixed bugs ~~~~~~~~~~ * [osclients] Custom auth mechanism was used for zaqarclient instead of unified keystonesession, which led to auth errors at some envs. * [plugins] During running `CinderVolumes.create_and_restore_volume_backup <http://rally.readthedocs.io/en/0.9.0/plugins/plugin_reference.html#cindervolumes-create-and-restore-volume-backup-scenario>`_ scenario we had a race problem with backup deleting due to wrong check of backup status. * [plugins][verifications] Jenkins expexts "classname" JUnitXML attribute instead of "class_name". Thanks ~~~~~~ 2 Everybody!

commit_message:
Move to tooz hash ring implementation

This changes the ironic driver to use the hash ring implementation from
tooz, which is nearly identical to nova.hash_ring.

Change-Id: I95716057cb1860b1357a61f3396f27ed878964e8
Depends-On: Ic1f8b89b819ace8df9b15c61eaf9bf136ad3166b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/22/399022/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # Copyright 2013 Hewlett-Packard Development Company, L.P. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import bisect import hashlib import six from nova import exception from nova.i18n import _ # NOTE(jroll) these constants will be config options in Ocata, when the hash # ring code is in oslo. # Number of partitions per service is 2^PARTITION_EXPONENT. # 5 should be fine for most deployments, as an experimental feature. PARTITION_EXPONENT = 5 # This should always be 1 in nova, as two compute daemons handling the same # node should not be possible. DISTRIBUTION_REPLICAS = 1 class HashRing(object): """A stable hash ring. We map item N to a host Y based on the closest lower hash: - hash(item) -> partition - hash(host) -> divider - closest lower divider is the host to use - we hash each host many times to spread load more finely as otherwise adding a host gets (on average) 50% of the load of just one other host assigned to it. """ def __init__(self, hosts): """Create a new hash ring across the specified hosts. :param hosts: an iterable of hosts which will be mapped. """ replicas = DISTRIBUTION_REPLICAS try: self.hosts = set(hosts) self.replicas = replicas if replicas <= len(hosts) else len(hosts) except TypeError: raise exception.Invalid( _("Invalid hosts supplied when building HashRing.")) self._host_hashes = {} for host in hosts: key = str(host).encode('utf8') key_hash = hashlib.md5(key) for p in range(2 ** PARTITION_EXPONENT): key_hash.update(key) hashed_key = self._hash2int(key_hash) self._host_hashes[hashed_key] = host # Gather the (possibly colliding) resulting hashes into a bisectable # list. self._partitions = sorted(self._host_hashes.keys()) def _hash2int(self, key_hash): """Convert the given hash's digest to a numerical value for the ring. :returns: An integer equivalent value of the digest. """ return int(key_hash.hexdigest(), 16) def _get_partition(self, data): try: if six.PY3 and data is not None: data = data.encode('utf-8') key_hash = hashlib.md5(data) hashed_key = self._hash2int(key_hash) position = bisect.bisect(self._partitions, hashed_key) return position if position < len(self._partitions) else 0 except TypeError: raise exception.Invalid( _("Invalid data supplied to HashRing.get_hosts.")) def get_hosts(self, data, ignore_hosts=None): """Get the list of hosts which the supplied data maps onto. :param data: A string identifier to be mapped across the ring. :param ignore_hosts: A list of hosts to skip when performing the hash. Useful to temporarily skip down hosts without performing a full rebalance. Default: None. :returns: a list of hosts. The length of this list depends on the number of replicas this `HashRing` was created with. It may be less than this if ignore_hosts is not None. """ hosts = [] if ignore_hosts is None: ignore_hosts = set() else: ignore_hosts = set(ignore_hosts) ignore_hosts.intersection_update(self.hosts) partition = self._get_partition(data) for replica in range(0, self.replicas): if len(hosts) + len(ignore_hosts) == len(self.hosts): # prevent infinite loop - cannot allocate more fallbacks. break # Linear probing: partition N, then N+1 etc. host = self._get_host(partition) while host in hosts or host in ignore_hosts: partition += 1 if partition >= len(self._partitions): partition = 0 host = self._get_host(partition) hosts.append(host) return hosts def _get_host(self, partition): """Find what host is serving a partition. :param partition: The index of the partition in the partition map. e.g. 0 is the first partition, 1 is the second. :return: The host object the ring was constructed with. """ return self._host_hashes[self._partitions[partition]]

commit_message:
add tests for alembic migration

There was the commit that removes vmware. It has alembic migrations,
but doesn't have any tests for that. This commit fixes that.

Change-Id: I66090b0a0d7bfbd8e2365ec027fabfefc9d612da
Closes-Bug: #1668249

commit_message:
tox: Build docs with Python 2.7

On systems that use Python 3 as default, the 'docs' target fails due to
a non-Python 3 dependency (feedformatter, required by yasfb). It's not
even clear if yasbf is still relevant, given the uselessness of the
content published online [1]. However, it's easier to just build the
docs with Python 2 than go on a wild goose chase looking for more info.

[1] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/rss.xml

Change-Id: I129f635bc2d060f9da9bfc8b43652be7c10e9200
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/06/445906/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: basepython = python2.7

commit_message:
Treat doc build warnings as errors

[pbr]warnerrors doesn't actually make the sphinx
docs build fail on warnings, and we have a ton of
garbage in the specs. pbr 2.0.0 removes warnerrors
so we should be using warning-is-error with sphinx
instead, which was introduced in sphinx 1.5 (we use 1.5.1).

Change-Id: Ibd087afd7a11f835d3bc74b7be1e9ccfbdcb1224
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/83/439883/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: warning-is-error = 1

subject: Re-add templates
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-03-15 17:00:00.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs/commit/1209190814d7f79df13f7306ef420593327ef2d4', 'message': "Add .keep files

In commit xxx, we removed templates from both the approved and
implemented folders of 'specs/{release}'. However, git tracks files, not
folders, meaning the 'implemented' folders for both Ocata and Pike,
which are currently empty, are no longer tracked.

Rather than re-adding the templates, simply add a simple .keep file in
each folder. This will keep the folder tracked without having any
bearing on output.

Change-Id: Iaae10e180845b5073e1e13a4df1050b8b98d03d7
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-03-15 17:28:30.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs/commit/160b89639d70dcbd09826f5ca9ecd5fd40398e8b', 'message': "Re-add templates

implemented folders of 'specs/{release}'. However, git tracks files, not
folders, meaning the 'implemented' folders for both Ocata and Pike,
which are currently empty, are no longer tracked and the glob patterns
used in 'doc/source/specs/{release}/index.rst cause warnings.

These templates are re-added to fix the immediate issue. However, we
still don't want to keep these around once the release has been made. As
such, we add an addition step to the tool for migrating implemented
specs to remove these templates. This should automate the process in the
future.

Change-Id: Iaae10e180845b5073e1e13a4df1050b8b98d03d7

commit_message:
Re-add templates

In commit a67d39ba, we removed templates from both the approved and
implemented folders of 'specs/{release}'. However, git tracks files, not
folders, meaning the 'implemented' folders for both Ocata and Pike,
which are currently empty, are no longer tracked and the glob patterns
used in 'doc/source/specs/{release}/index.rst cause warnings.

These templates are re-added to fix the immediate issue. However, we
still don't want to keep these around once the release has been made. As
such, we add an addition step to the tool for migrating implemented
specs to remove these templates. This should automate the process in the
future.

Change-Id: Iaae10e180845b5073e1e13a4df1050b8b98d03d7

Add magnum Cluster Template resource

Add resource for magnum. New resource `OS::Magnum::ClusterTemplate` will
used to deprecate BayModel.
Partial-Bug: #1625757

Change-Id: I5ab88127c01a8bcabf83bed17463686b21cc8c9a

commit_message:
More usage of ostestr and cleanup an unused dependency

Use ostestr as runner instead of the custome pretty_tox.sh script
(pretty much removed everywhere). pretty_tox3.sh is just a wrapper
for ostestr but it could be probably removed as well going forward.
Also remove the tempest-lib dependency, which originally provided
subunit-trace (now from os-testr).

Change-Id: I4390964ce83167d634b80f696e82a0e199582ce6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/36/437536/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: #!/usr/bin/env bash set -o pipefail TESTRARGS=$1 # --until-failure is not compatible with --subunit see: # # https://bugs.launchpad.net/testrepository/+bug/1411804 # # this work around exists until that is addressed if [[ "$TESTARGS" =~ "until-failure" ]]; then python setup.py testr --slowest --testr-args="$TESTRARGS" else python setup.py testr --slowest --testr-args="--subunit $TESTRARGS" | subunit-trace -f fi

commit_message:
This patch updates the logic behind the "if not service available
group" to check if the aodh and aodh_plugin are both installed.

Aodh has been added to the configuration boolean options to allow
for easy check with the if statement.

Change-Id: Ice22f095fc5fdbcb004ef8e6169f0d39fc76c023
Closes-Bug: #1611406

commit_message:
Spec for adding contrail support in kuryr-k8s

Change-Id: Ib6dd9138d0f85d218724cd18272bc978b171698a
Implements: blueprint kuryr-k8s-contrail-integration
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kuryr-kubernetes refs/changes/98/444998/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ========================================= Kuryr Kubernetes OpenContrail Integration ========================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/kuryr-kubernetes/+spec/kuryr-k8s-contrail-integration This spec proposes how to integrate OpenContrail with Kuryr-Kubernetes. OpenContrail is an open source project that provides network virtuaization functionality to OpenStack. Integrating these will allow Kuryr to be used to bridge container-VM networking in a Contrail-based OpenStack deployment. Problem Description =================== OpenContrail is one of the largest SDN platforms, but it currently does not work with Kuryr-Kubernetes. The goal of this blueprint is to provide Kuryr with the correct driver so that a Kubernetes-hosted container can use Kuryr-Kubernetes to correctly interface with an OpenContrail-based network. In this configuration, OpenContrail will take place of the Open Virtual Switch, L2/L3 functionality, etc. that normally comes with using Neutron as the default implementation. Use Cases --------- Kuryr will act as the container networking interface for OpenContrail. This patch set will allow a bare-metal, Kubernetes-hosted container to interact with VMs in an OpenStack virtual network. This means we have to have a way to plug, unplug and bridge the container. Use Case 1: Enable container based work loads to communicate with OpenStack hosted VM workloads in Contrail SDN environments Use Case 2: Allow Kubernetes workloads to leverage advanced OpenContrail based networking Use Case 3: Enable Kuberentes to create virtual networks via Contrail Proposed Change =============== This change will add a driver to Kuryr-Kubernetes that has all of the functionality of the CNI specifically for OpenContrail. The driver will feature the plug() and unplug() commands that grant the container network access. Community Impact ---------------- This spec invites the community to collaborate on a unified solution to support contrail integration within Kuryr-Kubernetes. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Darla Ahlert Steve Kipp Work Items ---------- 1. Implement an os-vif bare bones plugin similar to [1] only worrying about plug and unplug. We will implement this within Kuryr-Kubernetes for now and eventually merge this to openstack/os-vif. 2. Look into serialization for OpenContrail and use [2] as a reference, if needed. 3. Look into binding for OpenContrail similar to OVS binding [3] Added Paths for New Code: kuryr-kubernetes/cni/os-vif/opencontrail.py References ========== [1] https://github.com/openstack/os-vif/blob/master/vif_plug_ovs/ovs.py [2] https://github.com/openstack/kuryr-kubernetes/blob/794ec706c5fbe0da6e49bf20ba2439d8eb39ae7e/kuryr_kubernetes/os_vif_util.py#L258-L281 [3] https://github.com/openstack/kuryr-kubernetes/blob/794ec706c5fbe0da6e49bf20ba2439d8eb39ae7e/kuryr_kubernetes/cni/binding/bridge.py

commit_message:
flake8: Specify 'ironic' as name of app

Specify 'ironic' as the name of the application for the flake8-import-order
plugin. That way it knows that imports of ironic should come after external
libraries.

Change-Id: I3e6fb237b9846e8de1a071f3a659c23c44bc7f75
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/62/446562/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: application-import-names = ironic

commit_message:
task_deploy: no implicit conversion of String into Integer

Now Astute will not calculate fault tolerance groups and
critical node uids twice.

Change-Id: I3bf2dd0ffc0fc74fd9c670bd50b32e3285ae7e2a
Closes-Bug: #1669499
(cherry picked from commit 892894bfb534277642d91ad130515ca8465de582)

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-03-20 13:04:40.000000000', 'files': ['lib/astute/task_node.rb', 'spec/unit/task_node_spec.rb'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-astute/commit/8213652e49f0f2c28721dfb9da81ecb69d07f9c9', 'message': "Fix wrong ready status instead of stopped for stop deployment

which can be get if all tasks was passed with ready and skipped
statuses.

commit_message:
Fix wrong ready status instead of stopped for stop deployment

Report ready status for node means successful node status
which can be get if all tasks was passed with ready and skipped
statuses.

Same effect can be get if Astute mark node as skipped. In this
case we also get equal status 'successful'.

So we need ask node about skipped statuses before ask it about
successful status to prevent losing context about stop
deployment operation.

Change-Id: I3c042425cab800de0bfc4e03f29414b145f44983
Closes-Bug: #1672964
(cherry picked from commit 496212798efa9f167de20a3ea0c2146658b2b466)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-astute refs/changes/82/447482/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: it 'should report stopped if node skipped' do cluster.node_statuses_transitions['stopped'] = { 'status' => 'stopped' } cluster.node_statuses_transitions['successful'] = { 'status' => 'ready' } task_node.set_status_skipped task_node.stubs(:finished?).returns(true) task_node.stubs(:successful?).returns(true) ctx.expects(:report).with({ 'nodes' => [{ 'uid' => 'node_id', 'status' => 'stopped', 'progress' => 100}] }) task_node.report_node_status end

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-03-20 10:12:37.000000000', 'files': ['playbooks/roles/bifrost-create-vm-nodes/tasks/create_vm.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/bifrost/commit/a40dfaf9c3bb5d79d31f861b3a48b6bc1e795dc2', 'message': 'roles: bifrost-create-vm-nodes: Improve host matching when deleting from vbmc

Assuming that 'vm_name' is 'foobar' then 'vm_name in vbmc_list.stdout'

02:10:19.759738", "failed": true, "invocation": {"module_args":

commit_message:
roles: bifrost-create-vm-nodes: Improve host matching when deleting from vbmc

Assuming that 'vm_name' is 'foobar' then 'vm_name in vbmc_list.stdout'
will also match when there is a foobar[a-zA-Z0-9]* host registered so
there is a chance for the task to try and delete non-existing hosts
as obsereved below:

fatal: [127.0.0.1]: FAILED! => {"changed": true, "cmd": ["vbmc",
"delete", "jumphost"], "delta": "0:00:00.343033", "end": "2017-03-20
02:10:19.759738", "failed": true, "invocation": {"module_args":
{"_raw_params": "vbmc delete jumphost", "_uses_shell": false, "chdir":
null, "creates": null, "executable": null, "removes": null, "warn":
true}, "module_name": "command"}, "rc": 1, "start": "2017-03-20
02:10:19.416705", "stderr": "No domain with matching name jumphost was
found", "stdout": "", "stdout_lines": [], "warnings": []}

That happens because a 'jumphost.opnfvlocal' is registered in vbmc
but the 'vm_name' for this run is just 'jumphost'.

We fix this by using the 'find' method and looking for '{{vm_name}} '
instead.

Change-Id: I1675a978489bfd0633eabb30e2227ed7cb70c7ef
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/bifrost refs/changes/35/447435/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: when: vbmc_list.stdout.find("{{ vm_name }} ") != -1

commit_message:
Fix wrong ready status instead of stopped for stop deployment

Report ready status for node means successful node status
which can be get if all tasks was passed with ready and skipped
statuses.

Same effect can be get if Astute mark node as skipped. In this
case we also get equal status 'successful'.

So we need ask node about skipped statuses before ask it about
successful status to prevent losing context about stop
deployment operation.

Change-Id: I3c042425cab800de0bfc4e03f29414b145f44983
Closes-Bug: #1672964
(cherry picked from commit 496212798efa9f167de20a3ea0c2146658b2b466)

commit_message:
Remove tenant_id from compute endpoint

Since Nova API version 2.17, the tenant_id in the service catalog has
been optional (and recommended to not be used). This changes the
default installation instructions to not use it.

Change-Id: Id67ca1e31ea1e5ae0554bdada2a4cd62c5406b9c
See: Id92251243d9e92f30e466419110fce5781304823 for original change

The structure of the note file was also incorrect, so that is fixed at

commit_message:
fix update-cinder-doc release note

reno was ignoring the note because it was not in a known section, so
move it to the "config" section to reflect the fact that the changes
were in the configuration guide.

The structure of the note file was also incorrect, so that is fixed at
the same time to ensure that the YAML parser sees a list item with a
literal text block containing restructuredtext.

Change-Id: Id8977cb57adc6813140707da8ac501c544959d54
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/38/446738/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: config: - | 1. Remove the redundant configuration. 2. Add new features and storage system that Huawei cinder driver support.
deleted_lines: fixes: 1.Remove the redundant configuration. 2.Add new features and storage system that Huawei cinder driver support.

the patch being proposed. In cases where a branch name is specified,
only changes already merged into that branch (not submitted to it) are
included.

This patch adds the missing file using the convention used
elsewhere (calling it unreleased.rst). It leaves the release-notes
directive in index.rst because I'm not sure whether that's where you
want "published" notes to appear.

It removes the branch setting in config.yaml so that when reno is not
given a branch it uses the current branch by default. This allows
patches under test to be included in the build, so that formatting
errors in the notes will cause the build to break before the patches are
merged.

It also reorganizes the order of the release notes pages to match the
order used by convention and expected by the repository branching script
so that when this repo is branched the new release note page for the
series can be added automatically by the branch script.

Change-Id: Ibccdac675915ab3535f2b2fbc1f4daee6990048b
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

Change-Id: Ie795176a7e860e10acb2cfa2e9d21c1d08ba8a48

commit_message:
add a test page to the build structure for release notes

The release notes build needs a page that uses an unconstrained
"release-notes" directive so that the build in the CI system includes
the patch being proposed. In cases where a branch name is specified,
only changes already merged into that branch (not submitted to it) are
included.

This patch adds the missing file using the convention used
elsewhere (calling it unreleased.rst). It leaves the release-notes
directive in index.rst because I'm not sure whether that's where you
want "published" notes to appear.

It removes the branch setting in config.yaml so that when reno is not
given a branch it uses the current branch by default. This allows
patches under test to be included in the build, so that formatting
errors in the notes will cause the build to break before the patches are
merged.

It also reorganizes the order of the release notes pages to match the
order used by convention and expected by the repository branching script
so that when this repo is branched the new release note page for the
series can be added automatically by the branch script.

Change-Id: Ibccdac675915ab3535f2b2fbc1f4daee6990048b
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

squash

Change-Id: Ie795176a7e860e10acb2cfa2e9d21c1d08ba8a48
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/05/436505/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: scope=schema - allow_modify=true <https://openstackci.oracle.com/openstack_docs/zfssa_cinder_workflow.akwf>`__ Refer to `this link <https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E37831_01/html/E52872/godgw.html>`__ on how to download, view and execute a workflow.#. Configure cluster: If a cluster is used as the Cinder storage resource, the following verifications are required on your Oracle ZFS Storage Appliance: - Verify that both the pool and the network interface are of type "singleton" and are not locked to the current controller. This approach ensures that the pool and the interface used for data always belong to the active controller, regardless of the current state of the cluster. - Verify that the management IP, data IP and storage pool belong to the same head. .. note:: Most of configuration settings, including service properties, users, roles and iSCSI initiator definitions are replicated on both heads automatically. If the driver modifies any of these settings, they will be modified automatically on both heads. .. note:: There will be a short service interruption during failback/takeover, but once the process is complete, the cinder-volume service should be able to access the pool through the data IP.

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/16/446816/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Network hardware requirements ----------------------------- For a compute-focus architecture, we recommend designing the network architecture using a scalable network model that makes it easy to add capacity and bandwidth. A good example of such a model is the leaf-spline model. In this type of network design, you can add additional bandwidth as well as scale out to additional racks of gear. It is important to select network hardware that supports port count, port speed, and port density while allowing for future growth as workload demands increase. In the network architecture, it is also important to evaluate where to provide redundancy. Network software requirements ----------------------------- For a general purpose OpenStack cloud, the OpenStack infrastructure components need to be highly available. If the design does not include hardware load balancing, networking software packages like HAProxy will need to be included.

commit_message:
Make skip gnocchi option overridable

Since gnocchi is the default backend, We might want to be able to
override this option and let it skip by default for compatibility.
let user set it via extra_params.

Change-Id: I23e43552e14ced5a7da5e16ef323df3b1ec6722d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-ceilometer refs/changes/27/424127/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $dbsync_command = 'ceilometer-upgrade --config-file=/etc/ceilometer/ceilometer.conf'

commit_message:
Fix qemu-img: Not enough arguments error

qemu by itself throws an error. I added the --help flag and the
version number is still detected with the grep.

The version I'm using is 2.5.0

Also changed the reference in the docs.

Change-Id: I0a8d6161de464d09d76e5f5e50a1d9bb82f69e91
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/57/443757/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: local QEMU_IMG_OPTIONS=$(! $(qemu-img --help| grep -q 'version 1') && echo "--qemu-img-options compat=0.10")

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-03-09 19:07:57.000000000', 'files': ['trove/guestagent/pkg.py', 'integration/scripts/trovestack'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/adc8c7e02dde48c852693ff89c8d367d0319b9bb', 'message': "Don't use --force-yes

From the apt-get man page...

--force-yes

    Using force-yes can potentially destroy your system! Configuration

I replaced the two occurences in the trove project.

Change-Id: I7fd70cee456a890f15288425c91ba053efe4f7e9
"}]
commit_message:
Don't use --force-yes

From the apt-get man page...

--force-yes
    Force yes; this is a dangerous option that will cause apt to
    continue without prompting if it is doing something potentially
    harmful. It should not be used except in very special situations.
    Using force-yes can potentially destroy your system! Configuration
    Item: APT::Get::force-yes. This is deprecated and replaced by
    --allow-downgrades, --allow-remove-essential, --allow-change-held-packages
    in 1.1.

I replaced the two occurences in the trove project.

Change-Id: I7fd70cee456a890f15288425c91ba053efe4f7e9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/42/443942/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: "--allow-downgrades --allow-remove-essential " \ "--allow-change-held-packages --allow-unauthenticated -o " \

commit_message:
Add docs to tox.ini

This would make it easier to build and test docs locally.

To run the command you can type:
tox -e docs

This is common in most openstack projects.

If you try running "python setup.py build_sphinx" it will return:
"error: error in setup.cfg: command 'build_sphinx' has no such option
 'warning_is_error'"

commit_message:
Enable W503

W503 line break before binary operator

This moves binary operators which are after a line break to before
them.

Change-Id: I2ed881d27560bfb7038851df6e3d6d6307a21c80

commit_message:
Add fullstack test for containers with dual-net

Change-Id: Ia66db6d0fbb0bacbdeb3096d1e1bfa897f0ed904
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kuryr-libnetwork refs/changes/61/444661/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_container_ipam_request_address_with_existing_port(self): # pre-created Neutron network and subnet and port neutron_net_name = lib_utils.get_random_string(8) neutron_network = self.neutron_client.create_network( {'network': {'name': neutron_net_name, "admin_state_up": True}}) neutron_subnet_name = lib_utils.get_random_string(8) subnet_param = [{ 'name': neutron_subnet_name, 'network_id': neutron_network['network']['id'], 'ip_version': 4, 'cidr': "10.10.0.0/24", 'enable_dhcp': True, }] neutron_subnet = self.neutron_client.create_subnet({'subnets': subnet_param}) neutron_v6_subnet_name = lib_utils.get_random_string(8) v6_subnet_param = [{ 'name': neutron_v6_subnet_name, 'network_id': neutron_network['network']['id'], 'ip_version': 6, 'cidr': "fe80::/64", 'enable_dhcp': True, }] neutron_v6_subnet = self.neutron_client.create_subnet({'subnets': v6_subnet_param}) neutron_port = self.neutron_client.create_port({'port': { 'network_id': neutron_network['network']['id']}}) ipv4_address = None ipv6_address = None print("neutron_subnet: " + repr(neutron_subnet)) for fixed_ip in neutron_port['port']['fixed_ips']: if fixed_ip['subnet_id'] == neutron_subnet['subnets'][0]['id']: ipv4_address = fixed_ip['ip_address'] elif fixed_ip['subnet_id'] == neutron_v6_subnet['subnets'][0]['id']: ipv6_address = fixed_ip['ip_address'] fake_ipam = { "Driver": "kuryr", "Options": {}, "Config": [ { "Subnet": "10.10.0.0/24", "Gateway": "10.10.0.1" }, { "Subnet": "fe80::/64", "Gateway": "fe80::1" }, ] } # Create docker network using existing Neutron network options = {'neutron.net.name': neutron_net_name} container_net_name = lib_utils.get_random_string(8) container_net = self.docker_client.create_network( name=container_net_name, driver='kuryr', options=options, ipam=fake_ipam) container_net_id = container_net.get('Id') try: networks = self.neutron_client.list_networks( tags=utils.make_net_tags(container_net_id)) except Exception as e: self.docker_client.remove_network(container_net_id) message = ("Failed to list neutron networks: %s") self.fail(message % e.args[0]) self.assertEqual(1, len(networks['networks'])) # Boot a container, and connect to the docker network. container_name = lib_utils.get_random_string(8) container = self.docker_client.create_container( image='kuryr/busybox', command='/bin/sleep 600', hostname='kuryr_test_container', name=container_name) warn_msg = container.get('Warning') container_id = container.get('Id') self.assertIsNone(warn_msg, 'Warn in creating container') self.assertIsNotNone(container_id, 'Create container id must not ' 'be None') self.docker_client.start(container=container_id) self.docker_client.connect_container_to_network( container_id, container_net_id, ipv4_address=ipv4_address, ipv6_address=ipv6_address) try: ports = self.neutron_client.list_ports( network_id=neutron_network['network']['id']) except Exception as e: self.docker_client.disconnect_container_from_network( container_id, container_net_id) message = ("Failed to list neutron ports: %s") self.fail(message % e.args[0]) # A dhcp port gets created as well; dhcp is enabled by default self.assertEqual(2, len(ports['ports'])) # Find the existing neutron port neutron_port_param = {"network_id": neutron_network['network']['id']} neutron_ports = self.neutron_client.list_ports( **neutron_port_param) neutron_port = [port for port in neutron_ports['ports'] if (lib_const.DEVICE_OWNER in port['tags'] or port['name'] == utils.get_neutron_port_name(port['device_id']))] self.assertEqual(1, len(neutron_port)) # Disconnect container from network, this release ip address. self.docker_client.disconnect_container_from_network(container_id, container_net_id) ports = self.neutron_client.list_ports( network_id=neutron_network['network']['id']) self.assertEqual(1, len(ports['ports'])) kuryr_ports = self.neutron_client.list_ports( **neutron_port_param) kuryr_port = [port for port in kuryr_ports['ports'] if (lib_const.DEVICE_OWNER in port['tags'] or port['name'] == utils.get_neutron_port_name(port['device_id']))] self.assertEqual(0, len(kuryr_port)) # Cleanup resources self.docker_client.stop(container=container_id) self.docker_client.remove_network(container_net_id) self.neutron_client.delete_port(neutron_port['port']['id']) self.neutron_client.delete_subnet(neutron_subnet['subnets'][0]['id']) self.neutron_client.delete_subnet(neutron_v6_subnet['subnets'][0]['id']) self.neutron_client.delete_network(neutron_network['network']['id'])

subject: Create /etc/my.cnf.d/tripleo.cnf with proper bind-address
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-02-09 10:22:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo/commit/076bc8094c8a13bbbabd6704e1e581059ce546a8', 'message': "Create /etc/my.cnf.d/tripleo.cnf with proper bind-address

When fixing LP#1643487 we added ?bind_address to all DB URIs.
Since this clashes with Cellsv2 due to the URIs becoming host
dependent, we need a new approach to pass bind_address to pymysql
that leaves the DB URIs host-independent.

We first create a /etc/my.cnf.d/tripleo.cnf file with a [tripleo]
section and in this section we add the correct bind-address option.

The reason for not reusing an existing mariadb file (my.cnf or
galera.cnf) is that pymysql's ini file support is not robust
enough at the moment: https://github.com/PyMySQL/PyMySQL/issues/548

The reason for putting this file creation code in the haproxy
profile is the following: The slow VIP failover only happens if a
service runs where the VIPs exist. The VIPs get created in the
haproxy profile and that is why this is the most sensible placement.
I.e. if we added it to the galera profile and galera is split out
to a separate node, we'd still have the VIP failover problem.

Co-Authored-By: Damien Ciabrini <dciabrin@redhat.com>

Partial-Bug: #1663181
Change-Id: Iff8bd2d9ee85f7bb1445aa2e1b3cfbff1f397b18

that leaves the DB URIs host-independent.

We first create a /etc/my.cnf.d/tripleo.cnf file with a [tripleo]
section and in this section we add the correct bind-address option.

because the mysql one does not support custom sections *and* there

The reason for putting this file creation code only on the controller
nodes the following: The slow VIP failover only happens if a
service runs where the VIPs exist. The VIPs get created in the
haproxy profile and that is why in order to have fast VIP failovers
the MySQLClient profile must live where the Haproxy service is running.

commit_message:
Create /etc/my.cnf.d/tripleo.cnf with proper bind-address

When fixing LP#1643487 we added ?bind_address to all DB URIs.
Since this clashes with Cellsv2 due to the URIs becoming host
dependent, we need a new approach to pass bind_address to pymysql
that leaves the DB URIs host-independent.

We first create a /etc/my.cnf.d/tripleo.cnf file with a [tripleo]
section and in this section we add the correct bind-address option.
Note that we use the puppet augeas lens and not the mysql one
because the mysql one does not support custom sections *and* there
are older versions around which do not like the /etc/my.cnf.d/* path.

The reason for not reusing an existing mariadb file (my.cnf or
galera.cnf) is that pymysql's ini file support is not robust
enough at the moment: https://github.com/PyMySQL/PyMySQL/issues/548

The reason for putting this file creation code only on the controller
nodes the following: The slow VIP failover only happens if a
service runs where the VIPs exist. The VIPs get created in the
haproxy profile and that is why in order to have fast VIP failovers
the MySQLClient profile must live where the Haproxy service is running.

Co-Authored-By: Damien Ciabrini <dciabrin@redhat.com>

Partial-Bug: #1663181
Change-Id: Iff8bd2d9ee85f7bb1445aa2e1b3cfbff1f397b18
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo refs/changes/24/431424/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $mysql_bind_address = hiera('tripleo::profile::base::database::mysql::client_bind_address', undef) # If the folder /etc/my.cnf.d does not exist (e.g. if mariadb is not # present in the base image but installed as a package afterwards), # create it. We do not want to touch the permissions in case it already # exists due to the mariadb server package being pre-installed # Note: We use exec instead of file in the case that the mysql class is # included on this node as well (we'd get duplicate declaration in such a # situation when using file) if $mysql_bind_address != undef { exec { 'directory-create-etc-my.cnf.d': command => 'mkdir -p /etc/my.cnf.d', path => ['/usr/bin', '/usr/sbin', '/bin', '/sbin'], } -> # Create /etc/my.cnf.d/tripleo.cnf with the [tripleo]bind-address=<IP of the node in the mysql network> file { '/etc/my.cnf.d/tripleo.cnf': content => "[tripleo]\nbind-address=${mysql_bind_address}\n" } }

commit_message:
Remove extension in API layer

Extension is stablized now and no further development for it
so we can remove those todos in API concept doc.

Change-Id: I087caf4dec2d8dd281c2cf0a17aab4f43b081434
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/12/442312/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: Add separated rule for each API in extension ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ This is for provider better granularity for policy rules. Not just provide policy rule for extension as unit. This need user to move the policy rule into separated rule for each API. Enable action level rule override extension level rule ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ After separated rule for each API in extension, that will increase the work for deployer. So enable extension level rule as default for each API in that extension will ease that a lot. Deployer also can specify one rule for each API to override the extension level rule.

commit_message:
Update ci-script to enable TripleO gate dependencies

Gating tripleo-quickstart-extras changes with dependencies
on tripleo-quickstart changes is broken.
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/431760/ fixes the extras
gating role. This review updates the related ci-scripts
to utilize the role changes to gate dependencies.

Depends-On: Ieaaf230155dcc2cdaafede63be193306eeb40499
Change-Id: I952a05776f2abe56522931c29594a7c60c769bc0
