commit_message:
Fixes issues with raising mysql file limit

Changes Include:
 - Adds spec testing
 - Only raise limits if nonha.  puppet-systemd will restart the mariadb
   service which breaks ha deployments.  Hence we only want to do this
   in noha.
 - Minor fix to hiera value refrenced not as parameter to mysql.pp

Partial-Bug: #1648181
Related-Bug: #1524809

Co-Authored By: Feng Pan <fpan@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Id063bf4b4ac229181b01f40965811cb8ac4230d5
Signed-off-by: Tim Rozet <trozet@redhat.com>
Signed-off-by: Feng Pan <fpan@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo refs/changes/56/443756/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $mysql_max_connections = hiera('mysql_max_connections', undef), 'max_connections' => $mysql_max_connections, if $generate_dropin_file_limit and $manage_resources { 'LimitNOFILE' => 16384

commit_message:
Support PropertiesGroup validation in resources

Add PropertiesGroups validation to Resource validate
method and get rid of checks in resource plugins validate
methods.

implements bp heat-property-group

Change-Id: I42cb7bfc079130041f577410a386b5f369507c22
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/33/392633/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from heat.engine import properties_group self.properties_groups = properties_group.PropertiesGroups( self.properties_groups_schema, properties=self.properties) self.properties_groups.validate_properties_group()

commit_message:
String representation of PropertiesGroup

Add method to build string representation of PropertiesGroup
to get correct expressions of properties relations. Also,
add functional to validate all groups in PropertiesGroups class.

implements bp heat-property-group

Change-Id: Idbd52f2f16ba82b3dca152496717fcff53115eed
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/32/392632/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class TestPropertiesGroupsValidation(common.HeatTestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestPropertiesGroupsValidation, self).setUp() self.ctx = utils.dummy_context() tmpl = template_format.parse(default_template) self.stack = stack.Stack( self.ctx, 'pg_test_stack', template.Template(tmpl)) self.rsrc = self.stack['resource'] def test_validate_successful(self): self.rsrc.properties_groups_schema = [ {pg.OR: [['map', 'one'], ['int']]}, {pg.XOR: [['map', 'one'], ['int']]} ] self.rsrc.properties.data = {'map': {'one': 'check'}} pgroups = pg.PropertiesGroups(self.rsrc.properties_groups_schema, self.rsrc.properties) self.assertIsNone(pgroups.validate_properties_group()) def test_validate_failed(self): self.rsrc.properties_groups_schema = [ {pg.OR: [['map', 'one'], ['int']]}, {pg.XOR: [['map', 'one'], ['int']]} ] self.rsrc.properties.data = {'map': {'one': 'check'}, 'int': 0} pgroups = pg.PropertiesGroups(self.rsrc.properties_groups_schema, self.rsrc.properties) ex = self.assertRaises(exception.StackValidationFailed, pgroups.validate_properties_group) self.assertEqual('Properties group error: Properties don\'t satisfies ' 'next properties group expression: either "map.one" ' 'or "int"', six.text_type(ex)) def test_validate_complex_failed(self): self.rsrc.properties_groups_schema = [ {pg.OR: [['map', 'one'], ['int'], {pg.XOR: [['string1'], ['string2']]}]}, ] self.rsrc.properties.data = {'string1': 'aba', 'string2': 'caba'} pgroups = pg.PropertiesGroups(self.rsrc.properties_groups_schema, self.rsrc.properties) ex = self.assertRaises(exception.StackValidationFailed, pgroups.validate_properties_group) self.assertEqual('Properties group error: Properties don\'t satisfies ' 'next properties group expression: "map.one" or ' '"int" or (either "string1" or "string2")', six.text_type(ex)) def test_validate_double_complex_correct(self): self.rsrc.properties_groups_schema = [ {pg.OR: [['map', 'one'], ['int'], {pg.XOR: [['string1'], {pg.AND: [['bool'], ['list', 'two']]} ]}, ['string2'] ], }, ] self.rsrc.properties.data = {'bool': False, 'list': [{'two': 'check'}]} pgroups = pg.PropertiesGroups(self.rsrc.properties_groups_schema, self.rsrc.properties) self.assertIsNone(pgroups.validate_properties_group()) self.assertEqual('Properties group expression: "map.one" or ' '"int" or (either "string1" or ("bool" and ' '"list.two")) or "string2"', six.text_type(pgroups.groups[0]))

commit_message:
Add generic method to validate props relations

Add functional to validate correctness of properties
relations to get rid in future of checking relations in
resources' validate methods.

implements bp heat-property-group

Change-Id: I884b82ef15153dfa6e41cc47b924a8ad6fb21211

commit_message:
Add properties groups to doc generator

Added properties_groups_schema to resource as
list descriptions of relations between resource
properties and support it in doc generator for
displaying properties relations in documentation.

implements bp heat-property-group

Change-Id: I0a5f68730316348b473fb5077165701003786a75

commit_message:
Add props dependencies builder for PropertiesGroup

Added ability to get for specified property name relations
with other properties.

implements bp heat-property-group

Change-Id: I05b3005baecbb25cdf17957243bf1bb14b118a63
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/28/392628/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class TestBuildPropertiesDependencies(common.HeatTestCase): def test_simple_build_properties_dependencies(self): schema = {pg.OR: [['a'], ['b'], ['c']]} pgroup = pg.PropertiesGroup(schema) expected = {'a': {pg.OR: ['b', 'c']}, 'b': {pg.OR: ['a', 'c']}, 'c': {pg.OR: ['a', 'b']}} self.assertEqual(expected, pgroup.build_properties_dependencies()) def test_complex_build_properties_dependencies(self): schema = {pg.OR: [['a'], ['b'], {pg.XOR: [['c'], ['d'], {pg.OR: [['e'], ['f']]}]}]} pgroup = pg.PropertiesGroup(schema) expected = {'a': {'OR': ['b', 'c', 'd', 'e', 'f']}, 'b': {'OR': ['a', 'c', 'd', 'e', 'f']}, 'c': {'OR': ['a', 'b', 'd', 'e', 'f'], 'XOR': ['d', 'e', 'f']}, 'd': {'OR': ['a', 'b', 'c', 'e', 'f'], 'XOR': ['c', 'e', 'f']}, 'e': {'OR': ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'f'], 'XOR': ['c', 'd', 'f']}, 'f': {'OR': ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e'], 'XOR': ['c', 'd', 'e']}} self.assertEqual(expected, pgroup.build_properties_dependencies()) def test_get_property_deps(self): schema = {pg.OR: [['a'], ['b'], ['c']]} pgroup = pg.PropertiesGroup(schema) self.assertEqual({pg.OR: ['a', 'c']}, pgroup.get_property_deps('b')) def test_nested_property_deps(self): schema = {pg.OR: [['a'], ['b'], {pg.XOR: [['c'], ['d'], {pg.OR: [['e'], ['f']]}]}]} pgroup = pg.PropertiesGroup(schema) self.assertEqual({'OR': ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'f'], 'XOR': ['c', 'd', 'f']}, pgroup.get_property_deps('e')) def test_get_property_deps_with_excluded(self): schema = {pg.OR: [['austin'], ['bear'], {pg.XOR: [['check'], ['diablo'], {pg.AND: [['elf'], ['flavor']]}]}]} pgroup = pg.PropertiesGroup(schema) self.assertEqual({'OR': ['austin', 'bear', 'diablo', 'elf'], 'XOR': ['diablo', 'elf']}, pgroup.get_property_deps('check', [['flavor']])) def test_get_property_deps_all_excluded(self): schema = {pg.OR: [['a'], ['b'], {pg.XOR: [['c'], ['d'], {pg.AND: [['e'], ['f']]}]}]} pgroup = pg.PropertiesGroup(schema) self.assertEqual({'OR': ['a', 'b']}, pgroup.get_property_deps('c', [['f'], ['d'], ['e']]))

commit_message:
virt: implement get_inventory() for Ironic

This patch implements the new get_inventory() virt driver API method for
the Ironic driver. Included is a new functional test of the interaction
between the placement API, the resource tracker, and the scheduler
reporting client with respect to the change in the Ironic resource
reporting behaviour that corresponds to this change.

Change-Id: I59be1cbedc99dcbb0ccde089a9f4737305176324
blueprint: custom-resource-classes-pike

commit_message:
Add better support for multi-OS deployments

This change adds a few variables which allow it to consume a repo-server
setup which has releases based on OS and ARCH. The changes require a
deployer to have at least one repo-server per-OS type being deployed.
This means that if a deployer wanted to do a mixed CentOS 7 and Ubuntu
16.04 deployment they'd need at least one repo server in each of OS type
which facilitates the building of wheels for each OS.

Change-Id: Ifd5ff22ae47bc9a2a88c1bbb2632ce48ba5accbf
Closes-Bug: 1641131
Depends-On: I3f36afa307e02a38d73b860fc23ed94a09882c34
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
(cherry picked from commit cacf41028b1fe398175d34cc298ce39042edf09e)

commit_message:
Install psutil before starting memory_tracker

Part of the service is calling tools/mlock_report.py that imports the
library, and sometimes no other services pull in the dependency for us.
We should pull it ourselves.

Change-Id: I1830e396830134f8e3183d7bbbeacde305d3afe9

commit_message:
Add missing 'autospec' argument to mock.patch

Add missing 'autospec' keyword argument to mock.patch and
mock.patch.object calls. Use 'autospec=True' except for a few cases
where it fails because the mocked function is a @classmethod and it
doesn't work. In that case explicity set it to 'autospec=False'

Change-Id: I620dce91abaa4440e1803aeefb3e93c0b65d1419

commit_message:
bagpipe-bgp: make BGP port configurable

This allows the use of a non priviledged port on the BGP RR, and
also simplifies the deployment of multiple such RR with gobgp in the
fullstack setup (see I967ba442ef433b7ada5a1a381f1571ec3cf23517).

Change-Id: I8677ff933f94bde9a5841f8e60226904ff2517bd

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-03-20 13:38:50.000000000', 'files': ['nova/test.py', 'nova/tests/unit/test_mock_sanity.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/03c8ac6edee9cc46fead0104153125bd5b78365a', 'message': "POC: tests: autospecs all the mock.patch usages

By default, mock.patch's autospec argument is None, meaning that
there's no signature checking for the patched methods and funtions.

Wraps mock.patch methods to pass in a default autospec=True argument,

commit_message:
POC: tests: autospecs all the mock.patch usages

By default, mock.patch's autospec argument is None, meaning that
there's no signature checking for the patched methods and funtions.

Wraps mock.patch methods to pass in a default autospec=True argument,
if not already given.
Adds unit test to verify that the newly wrapped mock.patch methods work
as intended.

Change-Id: I3636833962c905faa0f144c7fdc4833037324d31
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/02/447502/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2017 Cloudbase Solutions Srl # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import mock from nova import test class Foo(object): def bar(self, something): pass @classmethod def class_bar(cls): pass @staticmethod def static_bar(a, b, c=None): pass class MockSanityTestCase(test.NoDBTestCase): @mock.patch.object(Foo, 'static_bar') @mock.patch.object(Foo, 'class_bar') @mock.patch.object(Foo, 'bar') def test_autospec(self, mock_bar, mock_class_bar, mock_static_bar): obj = Foo() obj.bar(mock.sentinel.something) obj.class_bar() obj.static_bar(mock.sentinel.a, mock.sentinel.b) obj.static_bar(mock.sentinel.a, mock.sentinel.b, c=mock.sentinel.c) mock_bar.assert_called_once_with(mock.sentinel.something) mock_class_bar.assert_called_once_with() mock_static_bar.assert_has_calls([ mock.call(mock.sentinel.a, mock.sentinel.b), mock.call(mock.sentinel.a, mock.sentinel.b, c=mock.sentinel.c)]) self.assertRaises(TypeError, obj.bar) self.assertRaises(TypeError, obj.bar, mock.sentinel.a, mock.sentinel.b) self.assertRaises(TypeError, obj.class_bar, mock.sentinel.a) self.assertRaises(TypeError, obj.static_bar) self.assertRaises(TypeError, obj.static_bar, mock.sentinel.a) self.assertRaises(TypeError, obj.static_bar, mock.sentinel.a, mock.sentinel.b, mock.sentinel.c, mock.sentinel.d) self.assertRaises(TypeError, obj.static_bar, mock.sentinel.a, mock.sentinel.b, d=mock.sentinel.d)

commit_message:
Propose VM and Bare-metal Platform Working Group

It is important we as a community make progress on problems that our
users (both people and machines) face while trying to access infrastructure
resources from the group of projects named here as the:
"VM and Bare-metal Platform"

This proposes forming a group of developers focused on ensuring progress is
made improving the user experience of this group of projects.

Not all working groups need a resolution, but this is more about putting
into writing that:

* these problems matter and need fixing
* it is OK for form a working group that has a scope that doesn't
  include all OpenStack projects.
* its the joint responsibility of a sub-set of OpenStack projects to
  work better together to make progress on these problems, including
  better understanding and documenting these problems.

Change-Id: If41b44188ae50adf38735d7dbfbdb068efbff6b4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/governance refs/changes/87/442387/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ===================================== Compute Platform Working Group (CPWG) ===================================== Over the past several years, OpenStack has experienced rapid growth in the number of projects within the ecosystem. In particular that has lead to the number of projects the Technical Committee are considering has experienced rapid growth. This working group is a group of developers who want to reach out both to each other and representatives of API Users and Operators to look at how to improve the user experience for those using OpenStack as the single platform to provide users with access to Bare Metal, Virtual Machines and Containers. This includes providing those resources with the appropriate access to both networking and storage. This should be a platform on which you can seamless run higher level services that make use of this base platform. For example, a database as a service project should be able to consume a users existing infrastructure quota and networks in a safe an controlled way. While the projects involved with this effort are expected to evolve over time, the initial projects considered in scope will be: * Documentation * Horizon * OpenStack Client * Keystone * Nova * Neutron * Cinder * Ironic The focus is on driving changes across all of these services, so when they are used together, the user gets a great experience. There is no aim to stop any service running outside this stack, its just out of scope for this working group. The agreements of this group will be recorded in a resolution repository, in a similar way to the TC. Each PTL, or a delegate assigned by the PTL, will have +2 rights on that repo. For something to merge all with voting rights must +2 the change, and agree to live by the decision. This means while it may not be your preferred solution, it is a solution you can go and implement within your project. This group holds the responsibly of making sure key decisions that are needed to ensure forward progress are made. When resources are not available for a particular effort, volunteers for those efforts should be sought from interested parties. The group is likely to not have IRC meeting, and instead use only asynchronous collaboration, such as e-mail and gerrit, to ensure equal engagement with all people across the globe. Examples of existing discussions that could be tracked by this group include: * Quotas * Capabilities API * Placement service (cross project scheduling) * Describe best practices of running containers with OpenStack (Magnum/Kuryr?) * Which DB to optimize for.

commit_message:
Use Sphinx 1.5 warning-is-error

With pbr 2.0 and Sphinx 1.5, the setting for treat sphinx warnings as
errors is setting warning-is-error in build_sphinx section. Migrate the
setting from the old warnerrors one.

There are only three related fixes required.

Change-Id: I84b020c18a8a1c7c11a35bacd61523bbb094abe4

commit_message:
scripts: test-bifrost.sh: Initialize the ZUUL_BRANCH variable

Commit afa9951dd92e2 ("Move database setup to bifrost") moved the
openstack_citest database setup from project-config to bifrost.
However, we need to provide a default (even if it's an empty one)
value for ZUUL_BRANCH (eg when running outside of zuul) in order
to not fail due to using 'set -u'. Fixes the following error:

./scripts/test-bifrost.sh: line 76: ZUUL_BRANCH: unbound variable

Change-Id: Iea1193ce0ac83013f4e41398b4e7ad9527d427ac
Fixes: afa9951dd92e2 ("Move database setup to bifrost")
(cherry picked from commit 1c1277bf760158dfd4127f239373ac4706a840f9)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/bifrost refs/changes/41/441041/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ZUUL_BRANCH=${ZUUL_BRANCH:-}

commit_message:
Remove old oslo.messaging transport aliases

Those are remnants from the oslo-incubator times. Also, oslo.messaging
deprecated [1] transport aliases since 5.2.0+ that is the minimal
version supported for stable/newton. The patch that bumped the minimal
version for Sahara landed 3 months+ ago, so we can proceed ripping
those aliases from the code base.

[1] I314cefa5fb1803fa7e21e3e34300e5ced31bba89

Closes-Bug: #1424728

Change-Id: I02fbe5f4f9f3bda80f4fc1ea94f852e1969ce1aa

commit_message:
roles: bifrost-ironic-install: Add PyMySQL dependency for ironic-dbsync

We are using MariaDB database for ironic so we need to install
the optional PyMySQL dependency for sqlalchemy on all distributions
otherwise ironic-dbsync fails with the following error:

CRITI [ironic] ImportError: No module named pymysql
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/ironic-dbsync", line 10, in <module>
    sys.exit(main())
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/ironic/cmd/dbsync.py", line 103, in main
    CONF.command.func()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/ironic/cmd/dbsync.py", line 35, in upgrade
     migration.upgrade(CONF.command.revision)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/ironic/db/migration.py", line 36, in upgrade
     return get_backend().upgrade(version)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/ironic/db/sqlalchemy/migration.py", line 56, in upgrade
     alembic.command.upgrade(config, revision or 'head')
  [...]
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/site-packages/sqlalchemy/dialects/mysql/pymysql.py", line 49, in dbapi
     return __import__('pymysql')
ImportError: No module named pymysql

Change-Id: Ib44779de06a7bad91a08e148e1c0e1eb9815afe8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/bifrost refs/changes/97/444197/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - python-PyMySQL

subject: Workaround for network start race condition
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-03-16 08:36:15.000000000', 'files': ['playbooks/roles/bifrost-create-vm-nodes/tasks/main.yml', 'playbooks/roles/bifrost-ironic-install/tasks/ironic_config.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/bifrost/commit/2292b62bd39e0aba776f6cf4947ba6d66ec6d506', 'message': 'Workaround for network start race condition

Add a workaround for the libvirt network start race condition bug. In
some cases the libvirt default network starts in an inactive state
with the bridge interface down. Trying to start the network via libvirt
fails because the network interface already exists. This condition is
checked for and ignored but causes the Bifrost deployment test to fail
later when templating ironic.conf as the configured network interface
has no IP address.

This change checks for the condition where the libvirt default network
is inactive and attempts to delete the associated bridge interface
before starting the libvirt network. This has been run through the CI
job and appears to resolve the issue.

Cherry-picking that because it will solve the continuous network
failures on ocata jobs.

Change-Id: Icb2baf0975ca3feb6041b2f2da9702ad6cc9fa06
Closes-Bug: #1660953
Related-Bug: #1650025
(cherry picked from commit 9c18eeac6d0072522e2537f3848b577ddb3a690d)
'}]
commit_message:
Workaround for network start race condition

Add a workaround for the libvirt network start race condition bug. In
some cases the libvirt default network starts in an inactive state
with the bridge interface down. Trying to start the network via libvirt
fails because the network interface already exists. This condition is
checked for and ignored but causes the Bifrost deployment test to fail
later when templating ironic.conf as the configured network interface
has no IP address.

This change checks for the condition where the libvirt default network
is inactive and attempts to delete the associated bridge interface
before starting the libvirt network. This has been run through the CI
job and appears to resolve the issue.

Cherry-picking that because it will solve the continuous network
failures on ocata jobs.

Change-Id: Icb2baf0975ca3feb6041b2f2da9702ad6cc9fa06
Closes-Bug: #1660953
Related-Bug: #1650025
(cherry picked from commit 9c18eeac6d0072522e2537f3848b577ddb3a690d)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/bifrost refs/changes/50/446350/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: "Fail if the network interface does not exist" fail: msg: > The configured network interface {{ network_interface }} does not exist when: "{{ 'ansible_' ~ ans_network_interface not in hostvars[inventory_hostname] }}" - name: "Fail if the network interface has no IP address assigned" fail: msg: > The configured network interface {{ network_interface }} does not have an IP address assigned when: "{{ not hostvars[inventory_hostname]['ansible_' ~ ans_network_interface].get('ipv4', {}).get('address') }}"

commit_message:
Fix doc build if git is absent

When building packages if git is absent, then we should not set
html_last_updated_fmt. It can still be set via the -D switch
when building with sphinx-build.

Change-Id: I153c8c7ce89c7f8ed498d22cf24459054ac9b8d4
Closes-Bug: #1552251

subject: Use kolla_internal_vip_address for glance_api servers
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-11-21 10:58:54.000000000', 'files': ['ansible/roles/nova/templates/nova.conf.j2', 'ansible/roles/cinder/templates/cinder.conf.j2'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible/commit/ac3e4cf9c9b84e43c39cc928ddd1f07687ad2b72', 'message': 'Use kolla_internal_vip_address for glance_api servers

Nova and Cinder used a list of glance api servers - this list
does not provide a proper high availability because the servers
are connected at random without recalling who is failed last
time. E.g. out of three controllers with a failed first one nova
and cinder can try connection to the first controller because of
random / shuffled choice of the glance server. A proper solution
is to use VIP that connects to alive server from the beginning.
Also as workaround one could significantly increase max number
of retries in configuration files in hope that a random function
will choose a healthy glance server sometime - not a good choice.

Change-Id: Ifaf8ffe3697ec88a6da4c2b43c83975b63dc2e8c
Closes-Bug: #1643509
'}]
commit_message:
Use kolla_internal_vip_address for glance_api servers

Nova and Cinder used a list of glance api servers - this list
does not provide a proper high availability because the servers
are connected at random without recalling who is failed last
time. E.g. out of three controllers with a failed first one nova
and cinder can try connection to the first controller because of
random / shuffled choice of the glance server. A proper solution
is to use VIP that connects to alive server from the beginning.
Also as workaround one could significantly increase max number
of retries in configuration files in hope that a random function
will choose a healthy glance server sometime - not a good choice.

Change-Id: Ifaf8ffe3697ec88a6da4c2b43c83975b63dc2e8c
Closes-Bug: #1643509
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/87/400187/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: glance_api_servers = {{ internal_protocol }}://{% if orchestration_engine == 'KUBERNETES' %}glance-api{% else %}{{ kolla_internal_vip_address }}{% endif %}:{{ glance_api_port }}
deleted_lines: glance_api_servers = {% for host in groups['glance-api'] %}{{ internal_protocol }}://{% if orchestration_engine == 'KUBERNETES' %}glance-api{% else %}{{ hostvars[host]['ansible_' + hostvars[host]['api_interface']]['ipv4']['address'] }}{% endif %}:{{ glance_api_port }}{% if not loop.last %},{% endif %}{% endfor %}

commit_message:
Error message should not include SQL command

There is SQL command included in the http response for conflicting
resource provider. We should remove SQL related errors from the
error message.

Change-Id: I47726919f9a2d2a767564909f454c334e42ffbe0
Closes-bug: 1664117

commit_message:
nova-status: require placement >= 1.4

Since Ia1a0066dc30025c02553584a077365b28d8ff80e FilterScheduler will
no longer fall back to not using placement API. We need to require
version 1.4 to prevent NoValidHost errors.

Closes-Bug: #1669433

Change-Id: I6666cb2f558ed1f4e83f21e0317a206b07c25134
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/81/441881/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(rpodolyaka): 1.4 is needed after CR 436180 was merged as # FilterScheduler will no longer fall back to not using placement needs_version = 1.4
deleted_lines: # The required version is a bit tricky but we know that we at least # need 1.0 for Newton computes. This minimum might change in the # future. needs_version = 1.0

commit_message:
Add quota limit check and enhance roll back for cg create

when a consistency group is created from a source consistency group
and the number of volumes associated with the source CG exceeds
the volumes quota, the creation of the CG will fail and will leave
volumes in "creating".

This patch add the quota limit check and also let the new created
volumes can be deleted if error occured.

Change-Id: I4f2ce1999c0eee798e2f4650a940d7335c548d40
Closes-bug: #1609889

commit_message:
[ha-guide-draft] Create ha-guide draft directory

This creates a new ha-guide-draft directory to allow developing the
guide. Add infrastructure for:
* The draft guide is not translated currently.
* Build RST version (but not PDF yet) with each run.
* Publish guide as draft
* Update built index for it.

Also updates the ToC to reflect the proposed changes.

Implements: blueprint implement-ha-guide-todos

Change-Id: If6f65646e02ac3eac08c288fd727ab9851cf9569
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/90/440890/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: =============================================== Database (Galera Cluster) for high availability =============================================== .. toctree:: :maxdepth: 2 shared-database-configure.rst shared-database-manage.rst The first step is to install the database that sits at the heart of the cluster. To implement high availability, run an instance of the database on each controller node and use Galera Cluster to provide replication between them. Galera Cluster is a synchronous multi-master database cluster, based on MySQL and the InnoDB storage engine. It is a high-availability service that provides high system uptime, no data loss, and scalability for growth. You can achieve high availability for the OpenStack database in many different ways, depending on the type of database that you want to use. There are three implementations of Galera Cluster available to you: - `Galera Cluster for MySQL <http://galeracluster.com/>`_: The MySQL reference implementation from Codership, Oy. - `MariaDB Galera Cluster <https://mariadb.org/>`_: The MariaDB implementation of Galera Cluster, which is commonly supported in environments based on Red Hat distributions. - `Percona XtraDB Cluster <http://www.percona.com/>`_: The XtraDB implementation of Galera Cluster from Percona. In addition to Galera Cluster, you can also achieve high availability through other database options, such as PostgreSQL, which has its own replication system.

commit_message:
Local copy of scenario test base class

The scenario tests base class from Tempest is not a stable interface
and it's going to be refactored on Tempest side, as notified in

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-February/112938.html

Maintain a local copy of the base class, taken from Tempest with head of
master at c5f1064759fe6c75a4bc5dc251ed1661845936cb.

Change-Id: Idfa5ebe18c794c51e406156fb120d128478d4f1e

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-03-17 17:55:06.000000000', 'files': ['lib/astute/task_node.rb', 'spec/unit/task_node_spec.rb'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-astute/commit/496212798efa9f167de20a3ea0c2146658b2b466', 'message': "Fix wrong ready status instead of stopped for stop deployment

Report ready status for node means successful node status

Change-Id: I3c042425cab800de0bfc4e03f29414b145f44983
Closes-Bug: #1672964
"}]
commit_message:
Fix wrong ready status instead of stopped for stop deployment

Report ready status for node means successful node status
which can be get if all tasks was passed with ready and skipped
statuses.

Same effect can be get if Astute mark node as skipped. In this
case we also get equal status 'successful'.

So we need ask node about skipped statuses before ask it about
successful status to prevent losing context about stop
deployment operation.

Change-Id: I3c042425cab800de0bfc4e03f29414b145f44983
Closes-Bug: #1672964
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-astute refs/changes/83/447083/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add handling of exit code 100 from timmy.

Diagnostic snapshot returns "Timmy: exit code 100" in the case of
insufficient disk space. In the manual docs of timmy such exit code
has more detailed description.

Change-Id: Idb2a3c31d32025e990c981ff5717309a4a536589
Closes-Bug: #1671455
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-astute refs/changes/78/446978/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: elsif result[:data][:exit_code] == 100 Astute.logger.error("#{ctx.task_id}: Not enough free space for logs. Decrease logs coefficient via CLI or config or free up space.") report_error(ctx, "Timmy exit code: #{result[:data][:exit_code]}. Not enough free space for logs.")

Remove horizon related config for firewall v2

Firewall v2 is not supported by horizon yet [1], related config should
be removed from the guide.

[1]: https://github.com/openstack/horizon/blob/master/openstack_dashboard/dashboards/project/firewalls/panel.py#L36

Change-Id: I31b8785713c32400f7809d9179fd6702241d0979

deleted_lines: #. Enable the option in the ``local_settings.py`` file, which is typically located on the controller node: .. code-block:: python OPENSTACK_NEUTRON_NETWORK = { # ... 'enable_firewall' = True, # ... } By default, ``enable_firewall`` option value is ``True`` in ``local_settings.py`` file. Apply the settings by restarting the web server. #. Restart the ``neutron-l3-agent`` and ``neutron-server`` services to apply the settings.

commit_message:
Removing HNAS iSCSI driver information

Hitachi NAS Platform iSCSI driver was removed from OpenStack code
and its documentation should be removed as well.
This patch removes the HNAS iSCSI driver information from the
configuration reference.

Change-Id: Ia49757e6ecd71f9ea0042dbdcaeeb93ea1f86193
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/39/446639/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Hitachi NAS Platform NFS driverThis OpenStack Block Storage volume drivers provides NFS supportThe NFS driver support these operations:Before using NFS services, use the HNAS configuration and management We do not recommend the use of the same NFS export for different back ends. If possible, configure each back end to to `cinder.volume.drivers.hitachi.hnas_nfs.HNASNFSDriver`. * - ``hds_hnas_nfs_config_file`` - /opt/hds/hnas/cinder_nfs_conf.xml - HDP (export) where the volumes will be created. Use exports paths to configure this. For HNAS NFS cinder driver, the snapshots of volumes are clones of volumes that were created using :command:`file-clone-create`, not the HNAS :command:`snapshot-\*` feature. Check the HNAS usersBelow are configuration examples for NFS backend:
deleted_lines: Hitachi NAS Platform iSCSI and NFS driversThis OpenStack Block Storage volume drivers provides iSCSI and NFS supportThe NFS and iSCSI drivers support these operations:Before using iSCSI and NFS services, use the HNAS configuration and management3. For iSCSI: * You must set an iSCSI domain to EVS. We do not recommend the use of the same NFS export or file system (iSCSI driver) for different back ends. If possible, configure each back end to to `cinder.volume.drivers.hitachi.hnas_iscsi.HNASISCSIDriver` for the iSCSI back end or `cinder.volume.drivers.hitachi.hnas_nfs.HNASNFSDriver` for the NFS back end. * - ``hnas_chap_enabled`` - Optional (iSCSI only) - True - Boolean tag used to enable CHAP authentication protocol for iSCSI driver. * - ``hds_hnas_nfs_config_file | hds_hnas_iscsi_config_file`` - /opt/hds/hnas/cinder_[nfs|iscsi]_conf.xml - HDP (export or file system) where the volumes will be created. Use exports paths for the NFS backend or the file system names for the iSCSI backend (note that when using the file system name, it does not contain the IP addresses of the HDP) * - ``hnas_svcX_iscsi_ip`` - Required (only for iSCSI) - N/A - The IP of the EVS that contains the file system specified in hnas_svcX_hdpFor NFS: For iSCSI: #. Under the :menuselection:`System > Volumes` tab, choose the option :guilabel:`Manage Volume`. #. Fill the fields :guilabel:`Identifier`, :guilabel:`Host`, :guilabel:`Volume Name`, and :guilabel:`Volume Type` with volume information to be managed: * :guilabel:`Identifier`: filesystem-name/volume-name (*For example:* filesystem-test/volume-test) * :guilabel:`Host`: `host@backend-name#pool_name` (*For example:* `ubuntu@hnas-iscsi#test_silver`) * :guilabel:`Volume Name`: volume_name (*For example:* volume-test) * :guilabel:`Volume Type`: choose a type of volume (*For example:* silver) For NFS: For iSCSI: .. code-block:: console $ cinder manage --name volume-test --volume-type silver ubuntu@hnas-iscsi#test_silver filesystem-test/volume-test For HNAS NFS cinder driver, the snapshots of volumes are clones of volumes that where created using :command:`file-clone-create`, not the HNAS :command:`snapshot-\*` feature. Check the HNAS users For NFS: Below are configuration examples for both NFS and iSCSI backends:#. HNAS iSCSI Driver #. For HNAS iSCSI driver, create this section in your ``cinder.conf`` file: .. code-block:: ini [hnas-iscsi] volume_driver = cinder.volume.drivers.hitachi.hnas_iscsi.HNASISCSIDriver volume_backend_name = hnas_iscsi_backend hnas_username = supervisor hnas_password = supervisor hnas_mgmt_ip0 = 172.24.44.15 hnas_chap_enabled = True hnas_svc0_pool_name = iscsi_gold hnas_svc0_hdp = FS-gold hnas_svc0_iscsi_ip = 172.24.49.21 hnas_svc1_pool_name = iscsi_platinum hnas_svc1_hdp = FS-platinum hnas_svc1_iscsi_ip = 172.24.49.21 hnas_svc2_pool_name = iscsi_silver hnas_svc2_hdp = FS-silver hnas_svc2_iscsi_ip = 172.24.49.22 hnas_svc3_pool_name = iscsi_bronze hnas_svc3_hdp = FS-bronze hnas_svc3_iscsi_ip = 172.24.49.23 #. Add it to the ``enabled_backends`` list, under the ``DEFAULT`` section of your ``cinder.conf`` file: .. code-block:: ini [DEFAULT] enabled_backends = hnas-nfs, hnas-iscsi #. Register a volume type with cinder and associate it with this backend: .. code-block:: console $ openstack volume type create hnas_iscsi_gold $ openstack volume type set --property volume_backend_name=hnas_iscsi_backend \ service_label=iscsi_gold hnas_iscsi_gold $ openstack volume type create hnas_iscsi_platinum $ openstack volume type set --property volume_backend_name=hnas_iscsi_backend \ service_label=iscsi_platinum hnas_iscsi_platinum $ openstack volume type create hnas_iscsi_silver $ openstack volume type set --property volume_backend_name=hnas_iscsi_backend \ service_label=iscsi_silver hnas_iscsi_silver $ openstack volume type create hnas_iscsi_bronze $ openstack volume type set --property volume_backend_name=hnas_iscsi_backend \ service_label=iscsi_bronze hnas_iscsi_bronze * iSCSI driver limitations: The iSCSI driver has a ``limit of 1024`` volumes attached to instances. * Hitachi NAS Platform iSCSI driver is now deprecated and will be removed on Pike release.

commit_message:
Fixes DBDeadlock race condition during driver initialization.

When multiple controllers are initially built, the ml2_vlan_allocations
will be empty and the neutron servers under different controllers will
try to populate the entry at the same time. This will cause this
DBDeadlock error as they try to access the db at the same time.

This patch set is to add db_api.retry_db_error decorator in the
_sync_vlan_allocations method to avoid this race condition.

Change-Id: I7c0e3ae515f592a5852e6decf6820b103f146761
Closes-bug: 1617499

commit_message:
Whitelist ldap group configs

The [ldap] parameters `group_members_are_ids` and `group_ad_nesting`
were not whitelisted before, and so domain specific config files
containing those parameters could not be uploaded. These parameters are
still valid and are generally going to be specific to their respective
domains, so they should be on the whitelist.

Closes-bug: #1670382

Change-Id: I955dc00b04f0ef81573e3f10ecabd3d182e59730
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/03/442103/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add CoreOS/K8s recommended defaults to kube-proxy

The cluster-cidr fix asymetric routing in specific
use case. Adding dbus removes iptables error message for kube-proxy and
adding ${HOST_CERT_PATH} is just common practice.

Change-Id: I8912091ebcb5c1ef940f43e5195a849f8fa6370e
Partially-Implements: bp coreos-best-pratice
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum refs/changes/18/439518/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - --cluster-cidr=${FLANNEL_NETWORK_CIDR} - mountPath: /etc/ssl/certs name: ssl-certs-host readOnly: true - mountPath: /var/run/dbus name: dbus readOnly: false - hostPath: path: ${HOST_CERTS_PATH} name: ssl-certs-host - hostPath: path: /var/run/dbus name: dbus

commit_message:
Add logstash.py detection plugin

This plugin detects the logstash proccess

* Fix pep

Change-Id: I6b3e6c145a9a9fe081a59ec79fa4dde5da6c2a26
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-agent refs/changes/54/446954/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import logging import os import yaml import monasca_setup.agent_config import monasca_setup.detection log = logging.getLogger(__name__) class Logstash(monasca_setup.detection.Plugin): """Detect Logstash daemon and setup configuration to monitor it. """ def _detect(self): """Run detection, set self.available True if the service is detected. """ if monasca_setup.detection.find_process_cmdline('java') is not None: self.available = True def build_config(self): """Build the config and return. """ log.info("\tWatching the java process.") return monasca_setup.detection.watch_process_by_username( 'logstash', 'java', 'logstash', 'monitoring', True) def dependencies_installed(self): return True

commit_message:
Modified repo build for better multi-OS support

The repo build role will now store all wheels and venvs in directories
containg information about the OS in which the bits were build on. The
intention here is to ensure that all installation are able to support
multi-OS without running into issues caused by system packages and
different core libs. This change builds upon the multi-archetecture
support we already have.

Closes-Bug: 1641131
Change-Id: I3f36afa307e02a38d73b860fc23ed94a09882c34
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
(cherry picked from commit fe3ae20f74a912925d5c78040984957a6d55f9de)

commit_message:
flake8: Specify 'ironic_lib' as name of app

Specify 'ironic_lib' as the name of the application for the flake8-import-order
plugin. That way it knows that imports of ironic_lib should come after external
libraries.

Change-Id: I6c88a6a8142634c1194832896f40f9bc9c122367
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-lib refs/changes/05/446605/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Detect monasca-api with WSGI as Python implementation

Since monasca-api can now be run as WSGI with apache server,
monasca_setup should detect this as a Python implementation
of monasca-api.

Change-Id: I8e42b1886de69538092d6314e39efdfe927820e3
Closes-Bug: #1673407
(cherry picked from commit 4857aac434016b100feff3b68d4e1c6f7427ff78)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-agent refs/changes/02/447402/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: _PYTHON_WSGI_CMD_API = ('/usr/sbin/httpd-prefork (wsgi:monasca-api)' '-f /etc/apache2/httpd.conf' '-DSYSCONFIG -DSYSTEMD' '-C PidFile /var/run/httpd.pid' '-C Include /etc/apache2/sysconfig.d/' '-DFOREGROUND -k start') @mock.patch('monasca_setup.detection.plugins.mon._MonAPIPythonHelper') def test_should_use_python_helper_if_api_is_wsgi(self, impl_helper): FakeProcesses.cmdLine = [_PYTHON_WSGI_CMD_API] self._mon_api._init_impl_helper = iih = mock.Mock( return_value=impl_helper) self._detect() iih.assert_called_once_with('python') self.assertTrue(impl_helper.load_configuration.called_once) self.assertTrue(impl_helper.get_bound_port.called_once)

subject: Bypass min_part_hours check for the AIO
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-03-17 10:04:34.000000000', 'files': ['tests/roles/bootstrap-host/templates/user_variables.aio.yml.j2'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/25c9a027977fe66d6ed36310d253ec36acd60712', 'message': 'Bypass min_part_hours check for the AIO

During the upgrade check for the AIO the swift rebalance
happens for the new version before an hour of time has
passed, resulting in a rebalance attempt failure.

For the AIO this bypasses that check as we have a fair
certainty in the AIO that the rings are balanced in less
time than the default minimum.

Change-Id: I1cec668460cef19d3514f92480f9a82166bf898c
'}]
commit_message:
Bypass min_part_hours check for the AIO

During the upgrade check for the AIO the swift rebalance
happens for the new version before an hour of time has
passed, resulting in a rebalance attempt failure.

For the AIO this bypasses that check as we have a fair
certainty in the AIO that the rings are balanced in less
time than the default minimum.

Change-Id: I1cec668460cef19d3514f92480f9a82166bf898c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/32/446932/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Reset the clock on the last time a rebalance happened, # circumventing the min_part_hours check. # This is here to facilitate the upgrade test and should # be used with caution! swift_pretend_min_part_hours_passed: True

commit_message:
devstack: Don't modprobe inside containers

When running in a container, the host must already have the modules
inserted in its kernel.

Change-Id: Ic61ad57557be5dd1319db70bfb50c23836874028
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/32/446232/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if ! running_in_container; then sudo modprobe nf_conntrack_tftp sudo modprobe nf_nat_tftp fi
deleted_lines: sudo modprobe nf_conntrack_tftp sudo modprobe nf_nat_tftp

commit_message:
Remove old oslo.messaging transport aliases

Those are remnants from the oslo-incubator times. Also, oslo.messaging
deprecated [1] transport aliases since 5.2.0+ that is the minimal
version supported for stable/newton. The patch that bumped the minimal
version for Ironic landed 3 months+ ago, so we can proceed ripping
those aliases from the code base.

[1] I314cefa5fb1803fa7e21e3e34300e5ced31bba89

Change-Id: I42dcc4b64f0b8e667abad68f7a5ed1ba004ec329
Closes-Bug: #1424728

commit_message:
Remove a deprecated fuel migration test

Change-Id: I1f9a0f909c823b4baf50891f943e0e4f8be8bbd3
Closes-Bug: 1671805
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-qa refs/changes/96/446496/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # Copyright 2015 Mirantis, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE_2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from devops.helpers.helpers import icmp_ping from devops.helpers.helpers import wait from proboscis.asserts import assert_equal from system_test import logger from system_test import testcase from system_test import action from system_test import deferred_decorator from system_test.tests import ActionTest from system_test.actions import BaseActions from system_test.actions import FuelMasterActions from system_test.helpers.decorators import make_snapshot_if_step_fail @testcase(groups=['system_test', 'system_test.fuel_migration']) class FuelMasterMigrate(ActionTest, BaseActions, FuelMasterActions): """Fuel master migration to VM Scenario: 1. Create environment 2. Run network checker 3. Deploy environment 4. Run network checker 5. Migrate Fuel Master to the compute node 6. Run network checker 7. Run OSTF """ actions_order = [ 'setup_master', 'config_release', 'make_slaves', 'revert_slaves', 'create_env', 'add_nodes', 'network_check', 'deploy_cluster', 'network_check', 'start_fuel_migration', 'check_migration_status', 'network_check', 'health_check' ] @deferred_decorator([make_snapshot_if_step_fail]) @action def start_fuel_migration(self): """Migrate Fuel Master to a compute""" # Get a compute to migrate Fuel Master to cluster_id = self.fuel_web.get_last_created_cluster() compute = self.fuel_web.get_nailgun_cluster_nodes_by_roles( cluster_id, ['compute'])[0] logger.info( 'Fuel Master will be migrated to {0} ' 'compute'.format(compute['name'])) # Start migrating Fuel Master with self.env.d_env.get_admin_remote() as remote: slave_name = compute['name'].split('_')[0] slave_ip = self.fuel_web.get_nailgun_node_by_name(slave_name)['ip'] result = remote.execute( 'fuel-migrate {0} >/dev/null &'.format(slave_ip)) assert_equal(result['exit_code'], 0, 'Failed to start fuel master migration') @deferred_decorator([make_snapshot_if_step_fail]) @action def check_migration_status(self): """Check periodically the status of Fuel Master migration process""" logger.info('First reboot of Master node...') logger.info('Wait for Master node become offline') wait(lambda: not icmp_ping(self.env.get_admin_node_ip()), timeout=60 * 10, timeout_msg='Master node did not become offline') logger.info('Wait for echo from Master node') wait(lambda: icmp_ping(self.env.get_admin_node_ip()), timeout=60 * 10, timeout_msg='Master node did not respond after reboot') logger.info('Wait for Master node become online') self.env.d_env.nodes().admin.await( network_name='admin', timeout=60 * 10) logger.info('Second reboot of Master node...') logger.info('Wait for Master node become offline') wait(lambda: not icmp_ping(self.env.get_admin_node_ip()), timeout=60 * 40, timeout_msg='Master node did not become offline') logger.info('Wait for echo from Master node') wait(lambda: icmp_ping(self.env.get_admin_node_ip()), timeout=60 * 10, timeout_msg='Master node did not respond after reboot') logger.info('Wait for Master node become online') self.env.d_env.nodes().admin.await( network_name='admin', timeout=60 * 10) logger.info("Wait for file 'migration-done' appears") with self.env.d_env.get_admin_remote() as remote: wait(lambda: remote.exists("/tmp/migration-done"), timeout=60 * 10, timeout_msg="File /tmp/migration-done wasn't appeared") logger.info("Migration complete!") logger.info("Wait for Slave nodes become online") self.fuel_web.wait_nodes_get_online_state( self.env.d_env.nodes().slaves[:2], timeout=60 * 20)

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-12 16:12:34.000000000', 'files': ['tempest/cmd/cleanup.py', 'tempest/lib/common/utils/data_utils.py', 'tempest/services/object_storage/object_client.py', 'tempest/scenario/manager.py', 'tempest/api/object_storage/test_container_acl.py', 'tempest/api/identity/admin/v3/test_default_project_id.py', 'tempest/api/object_storage/test_container_acl_negative.py', 'tempest/common/dynamic_creds.py', 'tempest/lib/common/utils/test_utils.py', 'tempest/api/object_storage/test_object_services.py', 'tempest/api/compute/servers/test_server_personality.py', 'tempest/common/utils/linux/remote_client.py', 'tempest/common/preprov_creds.py', 'tempest/lib/services/network/base.py', 'tempest/stress/stressaction.py', 'tempest/tests/lib/test_auth.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/e456dfdb31aeb6d3947e600d5bc7f6f1fbc16c01', 'message': "Replaces string concatenation based on '+'

Concatenating strings with '+' is usually considered an anti-pattern,
since strings are immutable. It generally ends up creating too many
intermediate strings which can be costly.

This patch replaces '+' string concatenation with one of the different
available options:

* .join() method on strings
* os.path.join when it's a filesystem path
* '%' syntax when needed

Change-Id: I5a071d03ac5c26e70bcb23482a5f079422577910
"}]
commit_message:
Replaces string concatenation based on '+'

Concatenating strings with '+' is usually considered an anti-pattern,
since strings are immutable. It generally ends up creating too many
intermediate strings which can be costly.

This patch replaces '+' string concatenation with one of the different
available options:

* .join() method on strings
* os.path.join when it's a filesystem path
* '%' syntax when needed

Change-Id: I5a071d03ac5c26e70bcb23482a5f079422577910

commit_message:
Drop localrc references

devstack-gate supports local.conf over localrc now:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/326585/

This broke our tempest check, so dropping the only element filling
localrc file (sourcing devstackgaterc is needed all the time anyway to
get the DEVSTACK_GATE_TEMPEST_REGEX variable)

Change-Id: I9ee5e18cc5c879de500517e9c663ce99d01218d6
Closes-Bug: 1667485
(cherry picked from commit f081f642525b6027f1cad114d3d835bfd507e7dc)

commit_message:
flake8: Specify 'ironic_python_agent' as name of app

Specify 'ironic_python_agent' as the name of the application for the
flake8-import-order plugin. That way it knows that imports of
ironic_python_agent should come after external libraries.

Change-Id: Id39d558a51aeb97d96633afea28676634547d0d7

commit_message:
Modified repo build for better multi-OS support

The repo build role will now store all wheels and venvs in directories
containg information about the OS in which the bits were build on. The
intention here is to ensure that all installation are able to support
multi-OS without running into issues caused by system packages and
different core libs. This change builds upon the multi-archetecture
support we already have.

Closes-Bug: 1641131
Change-Id: I3f36afa307e02a38d73b860fc23ed94a09882c34
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
(cherry picked from commit fe3ae20f74a912925d5c78040984957a6d55f9de)

commit_message:
Add populate_retry to schedule_and_build_instances

When boot an instance and failed on the compute node, nova will
not retry to boot on other host.

Since https://review.openstack.org/#/c/319379/ change the create
instance workflow and called schedule_and_build_instances which
not populate the retry into filter properties. So nova will not
retry when boot on compute fail. This patch populate retry to
instance properties when call schedule_and_build_instances.

Conflicts:
	nova/tests/functional/regressions/test_bug_1671648.py

NOTE(mriedem): The conflict is due to putting the functional
test fix before this bug fix in the backport series.

Change-Id: Ifdaddcd265a7fe8282499e27043936f8212610ad
Closes-Bug: #1671648
(cherry picked from commit cb4ce72f5f092644aa9b84fa58bcb9fd89b6bedc)

commit_message:
Implement "Add" rule for Translation

"Add" rule allows to merge lists and exists
only for it.

Change-Id: Idda890e794d52ee4b38dc88a90a41393c7557a65
Closes-bug: #1620859
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/20/420020/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if rule.rule is TranslationRule.ADD: result = self.add(key, rule, result, prop_data) def add(self, key, add_rule, prop_value=None, prop_data=None): value_path = add_rule.get_value_absolute_path() if prop_value is None: prop_value = [] if not isinstance(prop_value, list): raise ValueError(_('Incorrect translation rule using - cannot ' 'resolve Add rule for non-list translation ' 'value "%s".') % key) translation_value = prop_value if add_rule.value: translation_value.extend(add_rule.value) elif value_path: if self.has_translation('.'.join(value_path)): self.translate('.'.join(value_path), prop_data=prop_data) self.is_active = False value = get_value(value_path, prop_data if add_rule.value_name else self.properties) self.is_active = True if value is not None: translation_value.extend(value if isinstance(value, list) else [value]) if self.store_translated_values: self.resolved_translations[key] = translation_value return translation_value

subject: Fix ReSizeStream
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-03-20 05:58:29.000000000', 'files': ['freezer/utils/utils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/freezer/commit/08b04e1c5d1f5153532b058d876fc86d222076c6', 'message': 'Fix ReSizeStream

Fix issue in 'next' method of ReSizeStream class. If StopIteration
error is rasen while doing "self.reminder += self.stream.next()", it
wasn't processed in 'except StopIteration' block.

We need to fix this as it leads to error when doing backup of small images,
which size is less than ReSizeStream chunk size.

Change-Id: I21dfba3967c6a582b273f0e342ca435b14db0a0a
'}]
commit_message:
Fix ReSizeStream

Fix issue in 'next' method of ReSizeStream class. If StopIteration
error is rasen while doing "self.reminder += self.stream.next()", it
wasn't processed in 'except StopIteration' block.

We need to fix this as it leads to error when doing backup of small images,
which size is less than ReSizeStream chunk size.

Change-Id: I21dfba3967c6a582b273f0e342ca435b14db0a0a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/freezer refs/changes/74/447374/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: next_method = getattr(self.stream, 'next', None) if callable(next_method): self.reminder += self.stream.next() else: self.reminder += next(self.stream)
deleted_lines: self.reminder += next(self.stream) except TypeError: self.reminder += self.stream.next()

commit_message:
consume ServicePluginBase from neutron-lib

Neutron-lib now contains the ServicePluginBase class and
thus is being removed from neutron [1]. This patch moves
all such references from neutron to neutron-lib in accordance
with the neutron-lib rehoming.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/441129/

Change-Id: I3e67db4d2ce4a900879b26c28b4e77fea4af1b68

commit_message:
Fix default live migration configuration

Using the qemu+ssh migration scheme requires tunneling through libvirt
to be enabled, since qemu does not natively support SSH based
migrations.

Since our default configuration uses a secure migration channel, we
should also configure libvirt tunneled migrations by default.

Change-Id: Ia389e78994da0f5f1cd99edeafeef13009906621
(cherry picked from commit cb89b3bee528d80859c8e02eb4c6aee08669767b)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_nova refs/changes/98/446498/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: live_migration_tunnelled = True

[upstream] Clean up and update the details page

Change-Id: I530054929f1cfc6c81b8421375db8e05b5d6b299
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/training-guides refs/changes/41/447241/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Archived exercises ================== Lego applied to Free Software contributions (15 min) ---------------------------------------------------- Lego applied to Free Software contributions These slides prepare students for the Lego activity, and ensure they understand the metaphors in use. The Lego in the exercise represents the code of a software project, in this case OpenStack. The students all take on roles that represent various facets of the OpenStack community, including upstream roles like Foundation and TC, and contributors like corporations, and unaffiliated individuals animated by unknown motives (free agents). The group is split into their new 'teams' at this stage. Facilitators can choose any way they prefer to do this (selecting teams, or allowing students to self-select). The recommended numbers are in the slides, but can be changed to suit the number of participants in the room. For a very large group, consider separating into two 'communities', which then have to fit their streets together to complete the session. Having more communities requires an extra level of coordination to reach `interoperability` between the results of their work. Give each person a nametag to wear, with their first name and their role written on it. For free agents, don't disclose who is distracted, controversial, or agreeable. The community will need to work this out on their own. Contribution Simulation (2 hour) -------------------------------- Ahead of time: ensure the existing Lego buildings are set out on a table, but not connected to each other. All the unsorted bricks should be available in several smaller boxes in a different part of the room, for participants to use. There is no need to display the boxes or instruction manuals. Once the students are separated into their new roles, and have an understanding of the project, begin the timer for the first sprint. During the five minutes planning time, encourage each group to get together and think about their project. If possible, give each group a corner of the room and access to a whiteboard or flipchart. For companies, ensure the CEO sets a direction, and the team is on board. Their responsibility is to deliver value to their stakeholders. For upstream, have them think about the community standards they want to set: they are responsible for the quality of the finished product. For free agent contributors, use this time to get them to understand their role in the simulation: explain their part as agents of chaos. They can get straight to work as soon as they understand their role, no need to wait for the timer to go off. The free agents should not be forced to coordinate among themselves: there are better results if they find out how hard it is to accomplish anything without coordinating with others. In theory, the free agents can decide to demolish things, too: try suggesting this option to one of them, see what happens. Suggestions of projects to work on: * Companies: big industrial items like a shopping mall, carpark, energy plant, datacenter, and hospital. * Free agents: community items like vegetable patches, bicycle paths, public artworks, playgrounds. For the controversial agent, problematic items such as a jail, skate bowl, and dog park. * Upstream: consider guidelines around consistency in the bricks used, how to connect the road and sidewalk between the buildings, the kinds of buildings they should request the community to make, and the things they simply will not accept. Make them understand that they are responsible for the finished product. Start the timer for building time, and allow everyone to start work. During each building phase, have mentors wander around the groups listening in and making suggestions, without actually doing any of the work or giving answers. The role of the mentors is to ask questions to orient the conversations among the teams. For example, during the first sprint it is common that the CEO and the PTL will face incompatibility of their plans. Mentors should ask the teams how to address those issues. In your interactions with the students, do not be afraid to provoke some issues. For example, bring up the idea of an API (a way of connecting the buildings to each other) with individual companies, but don't mention it to upstream, so that upstream are finally faced with the challenge of standardizing the API. You could also, in the second or third sprint, encourage one group to call for a meeting off the sprint cycle to sort the problem out. During the final five minutes of the sprint (review time), ask everyone to take their hands off the Lego, and gather around the in-progress street. At this stage, upstream get to vote on the changes, and anything rejected gets sent back to the contributing group to be fixed. Ensure upstream give good reasons for rejections, along with suggestions for improvement. Encourage Upstream to reject a few things early on, to try and ensure contributors understand the need to have Foundation on board before they throw something over the wall. At the end of the four sprints, ensure you take a group photo! Contribution Planning (2 hours) ------------------------------- `ODP slides <http://dachary.org/loic/openstack-training/training-student-project-sample.odp>`_ `PDF slides <http://dachary.org/loic/openstack-training/training-student-project-sample.pdf>`_ * The students use template slides to prepare a 5-minute presentation of their planned contribution * A sample presentation is given by the teacher, as an example * Each student group prepares a presentation describing: * the contribution they plan to work on during the online sessions * how they will engage with the Upstream * how it contributes to the company's agenda * and whom they will be working with * Each student group presents its slides to the class Previous trainings ================== ---------------------Etherpad ~~~~~~~~ https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/upstream-training-barcelona -------------------------------------------------------Etherpad ~~~~~~~~ https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/upstream-training-vancouver -----------------------------------

commit_message:
Consume ServicePluginBase from neutron-lib

Neutron-lib now contains the ServicePluginBase class and
thus is being removed from neutron [1]. This patch ensures
that bgpvpn uses ServiceaPluginBase from neutron-lib

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/441129/

Change-Id: I21ddb1a2bec55c54e418d8e90a3e65f5739029f1

commit_message:
Enable Ocata Amulet Tests

- Add Zesty as a supported series to metadata.yaml.
- Turn on Xenial-Ocata Amulet test definitions.
- Sync charm helpers to get Juju 2.x amulet compatibility.
- Keeping Zesty-Ocata Amulet test definitions turned off until the
  metadata.yaml changes propagate to the charm store.

Change-Id: I83a23735b1657a7b746c5cf0082130a6a9f5756b

commit_message:
Use uuidutils instead of uuid.uuid4()

Openstack common has a wrapper for generating uuids.
We should only use that function when generating
uuids for consistency.

Change-Id: Ibf54161c51108b3a5b0e260e647bd00a11dc753a
Closes-Bug: #1082248

commit_message:
Fix the update in odl lbaas driver_v2

As bug #1644466 describes, neutron LoadBalancerPluginv2.
update_loadbalancer() gives 3 arguments to OpenDaylightLbaasDriverV2.
update(), but OpenDaylightLbaasDriverV2.update(context, obj)
just have two input parameters, so fix it.

Change-Id: Ic38cbca2b5089ff5c5327e132fc28c70d0514331
Closes-Bug: #1644466

commit_message:
Prepare for using standard python tests

Add simple script to setup mysql and postgresql databases, this script
can be run by users during testing and will be run by CI systems for
specific setup before running unit tests. This is exactly what is
currently done by OpenStack CI in project-config.

This allows to change in project-config the python-db jobs to
python-jobs since python-jobs will call this script initially.


Change-Id: I9dad144497819b49c5740118d0a36c838da19ead
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/77/444577/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash -xe # This script will be run by OpenStack CI before unit tests are run, # it sets up the test system as needed. # Developers should setup their test systems in a similar way. # This setup needs to be run as a user that can run sudo. # The root password for the MySQL database; pass it in via # MYSQL_ROOT_PW. DB_ROOT_PW=${MYSQL_ROOT_PW:-insecure_slave} # This user and its password are used by the tests, if you change it, # your tests might fail. DB_USER=openstack_citest DB_PW=openstack_citest sudo -H mysqladmin -u root password $DB_ROOT_PW # It's best practice to remove anonymous users from the database. If # a anonymous user exists, then it matches first for connections and # other connections from that host will not work. sudo -H mysql -u root -p$DB_ROOT_PW -h localhost -e " DELETE FROM mysql.user WHERE User=''; FLUSH PRIVILEGES; GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON *.* TO '$DB_USER'@'%' identified by '$DB_PW' WITH GRANT OPTION;" # Now create our database. mysql -u $DB_USER -p$DB_PW -h 127.0.0.1 -e " SET default_storage_engine=MYISAM; DROP DATABASE IF EXISTS openstack_citest; CREATE DATABASE openstack_citest CHARACTER SET utf8;" # Same for PostgreSQL # The root password for the PostgreSQL database; pass it in via # POSTGRES_ROOT_PW. DB_ROOT_PW=${POSTGRES_ROOT_PW:-insecure_slave} # Setup user root_roles=$(sudo -H -u postgres psql -t -c " SELECT 'HERE' from pg_roles where rolname='$DB_USER'") if [[ ${root_roles} == *HERE ]];then sudo -H -u postgres psql -c "ALTER ROLE $DB_USER WITH SUPERUSER LOGIN PASSWORD '$DB_PW'" else sudo -H -u postgres psql -c "CREATE ROLE $DB_USER WITH SUPERUSER LOGIN PASSWORD '$DB_PW'" fi # Store password for tests cat << EOF > $HOME/.pgpass *:*:*:$DB_USER:$DB_PW EOF chmod 0600 $HOME/.pgpass # Now create our database psql -h 127.0.0.1 -U $DB_USER -d template1 -c "DROP DATABASE IF EXISTS openstack_citest" createdb -h 127.0.0.1 -U $DB_USER -l C -T template0 -E utf8 openstack_citest

Prepare for using standard python tests

Add simple script to setup mysql and postgresql databases, this script
can be run by users during testing and will be run by CI systems for
specific setup before running unit tests. This is exactly what is
currently done by OpenStack CI in project-config.

This allows to change in project-config the python-db jobs to
python-jobs since python-jobs will call this script initially.


Change-Id: I3dcd2bf111dd4bda727619cd0534396238b95561

commit_message:
XtremIO: allow a cloned volume with larger size

* In case the new volume is larger than the cloned one,
    resize the cloned volume.
* Added unit test for success and failed resize.

Co-Authored-By: Xinli Guan <xinli@us.ibm.com>

commit_message:
Add get_stack_template support for heat

This adds a function for fetching the template used by a heat stack.
We will use it to adopt an existing heat stack as a senlin node.

Change-Id: I2ddb9a8ccccc64589d5bca7942b687b2cf7ae5b9
Depends-On: Ic4ea1c58b8c43b2e4217b4a96195b338a3f4310b

commit_message:
failed to dump 'WARNING' notification

The failure is caused by unmatch definition.

1. source
https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/senlin/tree/senlin/common/consts.py#n263

2. dest
https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/senlin/tree/senlin/common/consts.py#n286

'WARNING'.lower() != warn.

Change-Id: I0faad4f62e2f1575c119ac80c2fa5de52b245570
Closes-Bug: #1674197

commit_message:
fix mon-data dir err when  CEPH_DATA_DIR is set

when CEPH_DATA_DIR is set ,dir /var/lib/ceph appear,
and exception occurs:
reson is the default --mon-data dir of  ceph-mon is
/var/lib/ceph/mon.
Closes-Bug:#1666164

Change-Id: I62c884b3807475d8edd9d672ec7905f999218acd

commit_message:
Log message don't use appropriate marker function.

Logging not using oslo.i18n guidelines (openstack)
Fix missing translations for log messages.
Guidelines can be found here
https://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.i18n/guidelines.html#log-translation

Change-Id: I67e1493b9044f6db49827f0bc235c78968d65e8d
Closes-bug: 1673641

commit_message:
Add timeout attribute to LBaaS v2 Listeners

The following patch adds the --timeout attribute with
to the lbaas-v2 listeners.
This option is available for both lbaas-listener-create and
lbaas-listener-update.

Depends-On: I6c5130b31946903e01fc368472ca85aa1bcb45b1
Change-Id: I69f8412776b5be20668a0d92f805b09bb09534b3
Closes-Bug: #1457556

commit_message:
Enable Heat in Devstack for Patrole

This commit enables Heat in the Devstack that Patrole uses. This
allows Heat tests to run in Patrole.

Change-Id: Icc30b7da4a955491e34eed26279a70bba6af5e32
Closes-Bug: #1673121
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/26/446726/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Enable Heat export DEVSTACK_LOCAL_CONFIG+=$'\n'"enable_plugin heat git://git.openstack.org/openstack/heat" - console-log

post git events to golang irc channel

Let's start with openstack/golang-client and openstack/golang-commons
logging to #openstack-golang IRC channel
